patients	O

.	O

16	O

represents	O
a	O

cell	O

generally	O

be	O
associated	O

disorders	O
and	O
very	O
rarely	O
present	O
as	O
mast	B-malignancy-type
cell	I-malignancy-type
leukemia	I-malignancy-type
or	O
malignant	B-malignancy-type

.	O

for	O
this	O

of	O

onset	O
disease	O

unknown	O

.	O

codon	O
816	O
mutation	O

PURPOSE	O
:	O
Kirsten	O

Beta-catenin	O
forms	O
complexes	O
with	O
Tcf	O
and	O
Lef-1	O
and	O
functions	O
as	O
a	O

activator	O
downstream	O
of	O
the	O
Wnt	O
signaling	O
pathway	O
.	O
Activation	O
of	O
the	O
pathway	O
by	O
stabilization	O
of	O
beta-catenin	O
has	O
been	O
shown	O
to	O
be	O
important	O
in	O
the	O
development	O
of	O
colorectal	B-malignancy-type
carcinoma	I-malignancy-type
,	O
which	O
is	O
mainly	O
caused	O
by	O
inactivating	O
mutations	O
of	O
the	O
adenomatous	O
polyposis	O
coli	O
tumor	O
suppressor	O
gene	O

by	O
activating	O
mutations	O
in	O
exon	O
3	O
of	O
the	O
beta-catenin	O
gene	O
.	O
Here	O

we	O
analyzed	O
mutations	O
in	O
exon	O
3	O
of	O
the	O
beta-catenin	O
gene	O
in	O
endometrial	B-malignancy-type
carcinoma	I-malignancy-type
cases	O
in	O
which	O
loss	O
of	O
heterozygosity	O
at	O
the	O
adenomatous	O
polyposis	O
coli	O
tumor	O
suppressor	O
gene	O
locus	O
has	O
been	O
rarely	O
reported	O
.	O

found	O
that	O
10	O
of	O
76	O
cases	O
had	O
beta-catenin	O
gene	O
mutations	O
.	O

were	O

missense	O

on	O

residues	O
(	O

33	O

37	O
,	O

,	O
and	O
45	O
)	O

altering	O
the	O
glycogen	O

kinase	O
3	O
beta	O
phosphorylation	O
consensus	O
motif	O
,	O
which	O
participates	O
in	O
the	O
degradation	O
of	O

.	O

whether	O

mutations	O
actually	O
led	O
to	O

of	O
this	O

,	O
expression	O
of	O

was	O
analyzed	O

,	O
and	O
9	O
of	O
10	O
cases	O

BACKGROUND	O
:	O
Epidemiologic	O
studies	O
of	O
acute	B-malignancy-type
myeloid	I-malignancy-type
leukemias	I-malignancy-type
(	O
AMLs	B-malignancy-type
)	O
show	O
small	O
increases	O
in	O
risk	O
of	O
disease	O
associated	O
with	O
certain	O
occupations	O
and	O
chemical	O
exposures	O
.	O

:	O

study	O
was	O
designed	O
to	O
determine	O
whether	O
the	O

of	O

in	O

are	O

with	O

and	O
chemical	O
exposures	O
.	O

:	O

a	O

trial	O
,	O
and	O
630	O
healthy	O
control	O
subjects	O

extracted	O
from	O
patients	O

by	O

with	O
allele	O
-	O

for	O
activating	O
point	O
mutations	O
at	O

12th	O
,	O

and	O
61st	O
codons	O
of	O
three	O
protooncogenes	O
:	O

(	O
also	O
known	O
as	O

)	O
,	O

(	O
also	O
known	O
as	O

(	O

:	O

ras	O

-	O
positive	O

(	O

;	O

%	O

ras	O

and	O

Death	O
associated	O
protein-5	O
(	O
DAP-5	O
)	O
is	O
a	O
ubiquitously	O
expressed	O
member	O
of	O
the	O
translation	O
initiation	O
factor	O
eIF4G	O
family	O
that	O
lacks	O
the	O
eIF4E	O
binding	O
site	O
.	O
A	O
dominant	O
negative	O
fragment	O
of	O
DAP-5	O
protects	O
HeLa	O
cells	O
from	O
IFNgamma	O
-	O
induced	O
cell	O
death	O
.	O
By	O
employing	O
a	O
functional	O
approach	O
we	O
examined	O
the	O
role	O
of	O

in	O
human	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
cells	O
that	O
are	O
sensitized	O
for	O
IFNgamma	O
-	O
induced	O
apoptosis	O
by	O
tetracycline	O
controlled	O
MYCN	O
expression	O
.	O
DAP-5	O
fragment	O
transcribed	O
at	O
high	O
levels	O
and	O
translated	O
into	O
a	O
functional	O
miniprotein	O
of	O
28	O
kDa	O
protected	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
cells	O
from	O
IFNgamma	O
-	O
induced	O
apoptosis	O
.	O
Reduced	O
serum	O
levels	O
were	O
toxic	O
to	O
cells	O
constitutively	O
expressing	O
DAP-5	O
fragment	O
suggesting	O
that	O
DAP-5	O
protein	O
is	O
essential	O
for	O
both	O
viability	O
and	O
death	O
of	O
human	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
cells	O

p73	O
gene	O
is	O
a	O
new	O

abnormal	O

gene	O

associated	O
with	O

malignant	O
melanoma	B-malignancy-type
,	O
prostatic	B-malignancy-type
carcinoma	I-malignancy-type

lung	B-malignancy-type

.	O

may	O

of	O
a	O

carcinoma	I-malignancy-type
.	O

and	O

carcinoma	I-malignancy-type
.	O

37232	O
.	O
The	O
glial	O
-	O
derived	O
protein	O
S100	O
beta	O
can	O
act	O
as	O
a	O
mitogen	O
or	O
a	O
neurotrophic	O
factor	O
,	O
stimulating	O
proliferation	O
of	O
glial	O
cells	O
or	O
differentiation	O
of	O
immature	O
neurons	O
.	O
We	O
report	O
here	O
that	O
dimeric	O
S100	O
beta	O
evokes	O
increases	O
in	O
intracellular	O
free	O
calcium	O
concentrations	O
(	O
[Ca2+]i	O
)	O
in	O
both	O
glial	O
cells	O
and	O
neuronal	O
cells	O
.	O
The	O
[Ca2+]i	O
increase	O
exhibited	O
a	O
rapid	O
transient	O
component	O
which	O
was	O
not	O
affected	O
by	O
removal	O
of	O
extracellular	O
calcium	O
and	O
a	O
sustained	O
component	O
which	O
appeared	O
to	O
require	O
influx	O
of	O
extracellular	O
calcium	O
through	O
Ni(2+)	O
-	O
sensitive	O
channels	O
.	O
S100	O
beta	O
also	O
stimulated	O
hydrolysis	O
of	O
phosphoinositides	O
,	O
suggesting	O
a	O
mobilization	O
of	O
calcium	O
from	O
intracellular	O
stores	O
.	O
These	O
data	O
suggest	O
that	O
although	O
the	O
final	O
biological	O
responses	O
of	O
neuronal	O
and	O
glial	O
cells	O
to	O
S100	O
beta	O
are	O
different	O
,	O
transduction	O
of	O
the	O
S100	O
beta	O
signal	O
in	O
both	O
cell	O
types	O
involves	O
changes	O
in	O
[Ca2+]i	O
.	O

Opsoclonus	O
-	O
myoclonus	O
(	O
OM	O
)	O
is	O
a	O
neurological	O
disorder	O
usually	O
occurring	O
in	O
infancy	O
,	O
clinically	O
manifested	O
by	O
various	O
involuntary	O
movements	O
.	O
The	O
pathogenesis	O
of	O
OM	O
is	O
unknown	O
,	O
but	O
since	O
the	O
disease	O
often	O
is	O
associated	O
with	O
viral	O
infection	O
or	O
with	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
,	O
an	O
immunologic	O
basis	O
for	O
OM	O
has	O
been	O
postulated	O
.	O
We	O
have	O
studied	O
two	O
children	O
with	O
OM	O
whose	O
serum	O
contained	O
antibodies	O
directed	O
against	O
the	O
210	O
kDa	O
neurofilament	O
protein	O
;	O
these	O
antibodies	O
were	O
not	O
seen	O
in	O
the	O
serum	O
of	O
21	O
children	O
with	O
other	O
neurological	O
disorders	O
.	O
Neurofilament	O
proteins	O
,	O
which	O
are	O
found	O
only	O
in	O
neurons	O
,	O
may	O
be	O
of	O
prime	O
importance	O
in	O
neuronal	O
function	O
,	O
especially	O
during	O
development	O
of	O
the	O
nervous	O
system	O
.	O
Our	O
findings	O
suggest	O
that	O
generation	O
of	O
antibodies	O
to	O
the	O
neurofilament	O
proteins	O
can	O
occur	O
in	O
patients	O
with	O
opsoclonus	O
-	O
myoclonus	O
;	O
the	O
role	O
of	O
the	O
anti	O
-	O
NF210K	O
antibodies	O
in	O
the	O
pathogenesis	O
of	O
OM	O
,	O
however	O

is	O
uncertain	O

The	O
p73	O
gene	O
is	O
a	O
p53	O

at	O
1p36.3	O
,	O
a	O

region	O
frequently	O
deleted	O
in	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
.	O

was	O
originally	O
considered	O
an	O
oncosuppressor	O
gene	O
.	O

was	O
soon	O

that	O

that	O
of	O
a	O
classic	O
anti	O
-	O
oncogene	O
.	O

recent	O

of	O

terminal	O
truncated	O
isoforms	O

with	O

properties	O

that	O

has	O
a	O
'	O

in	O
one	O
'	O

strong	O

of	O
apoptosis	O

of	O

.	O

are	O
part	O
of	O

against	O

in	O
cells	O

(	O
MLT	O

has	O
received	O
much	O

recent	O

cell	O

a	O

.	O

.	O
Zdanovskaia	O

53711-5399	O

USA	O
.	O
Clostridial	O
neurotoxins	O
are	O
the	O
most	O
powerful	O
toxins	O
known	O
.	O
Nevertheless	O
,	O
derivatives	O
of	O
these	O
toxins	O
may	O
find	O
broad	O
applications	O
both	O
in	O
science	O
and	O
medicine	O
because	O
of	O
their	O
unique	O
abilities	O
to	O
recognize	O
neurons	O
and	O
deliver	O
small	O
and	O
large	O
molecules	O
into	O
them	O
.	O
In	O
this	O
paper	O
we	O
describe	O
the	O
construction	O
of	O
two	O
types	O
of	O
such	O
derivatives	O
.	O

to	O
the	O
first	O
class	O
were	O
designed	O
to	O
allow	O
direct	O
conjugation	O
with	O
one	O
or	O
few	O
molecules	O
of	O
interest	O
.	O
Proteins	O
belonging	O
to	O
the	O
second	O
class	O
contain	O
biotin	O
residue	O
and	O
therefore	O

be	O
easily	O
connected	O
to	O
streptavidin	O
loaded	O
with	O
multiple	O
molecules	O
of	O
interest	O
.	O
Only	O
C	O
-	O
terminal	O
regions	O
of	O
neurotoxin	O
heavy	O
chains	O
were	O
incorporated	O
in	O
the	O
structure	O
of	O
recombinant	O
proteins	O
.	O
Nevertheless	O
,	O
recombinant	O
proteins	O
were	O
found	O
to	O
be	O
able	O
to	O
recognize	O
specific	O
neuronal	O
receptors	O
and	O
target	O
model	O
molecules	O
to	O
rat	O
synaptosomes	O
and	O
human	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
cells	O
.	O

INTRODUCTION	O
:	O
In	O
recent	O
years	O
,	O
many	O
scientists	O
involved	O
in	O
cancer	O
research	O
have	O
directed	O
their	O
attention	O
to	O
telomerase	O
,	O
an	O
enzymatic	O
complex	O
which	O
is	O
specifically	O
involved	O
in	O
duplicating	O
telomeres	O
,	O
the	O
very	O
ends	O
of	O
linear	O
chromosomes	O
.	O
The	O
discovery	O
that	O
most	O
immortal	O
cell	O
lines	O
in	O
vitro	O
and	O
human	O
tumor	O
cells	O
in	O
vivo	O
have	O
telomerase	O
activity	O
,	O
in	O
contrast	O
to	O
telomerase	O
-	O
negative	O
normal	O
somatic	O
cells	O
,	O
has	O
made	O
telomerase	O
a	O
candidate	O
for	O
use	O
as	O
a	O
molecular	O
marker	O
of	O
malignancy	O
and	O
even	O
as	O
a	O
target	O
for	O
anticancer	O
therapies	O
.	O
Thus	O
,	O
the	O
assessment	O
of	O
the	O
role	O
of	O
telomerase	O
activity	O
in	O
neoplastic	O
transformation	O
has	O
become	O
a	O
key	O
issue	O
in	O
oncology	O
,	O
as	O
stated	O
by	O
the	O
exponential	O
increase	O
of	O
papers	O
on	O
telomerase	O
in	O
the	O
last	O
5	O
years	O
.	O
OBJECT	O
:	O

this	O
paper	O
,	O
we	O
review	O

of	O
Tokushima	O

Japan	O
.	O
Immortalized	O
hybrid	O
cells	O

of	O
the	O
cells	O
from	O

cells	O

of	O

.	O

.	O

)	O

10	O

.	O

after	O
4	O

of	O

.	O

products	O

no	O

.	O

3	O

and	O

of	O

.	O

.	O

.	O

tagged	O
with	O

In	O

have	O
a	O

of	O

ranging	O
from	O
control	O
of	O

brain	O

functions	O

behavior	O
.	O

these	O
hormones	O
influence	O
the	O
manifestation	O
of	O
disorders	O
like	O
depression	O
and	O
Alzheimer	O
's	O
.	O
Study	O
of	O
the	O
cells	O
target	O
for	O
the	O
hormone	O
has	O
shown	O
that	O

(	O

)	O
are	O
expressed	O
in	O
all	O

.	O

have	O

.	O

Ganglioneuromas	B-malignancy-type
(	O
GNs	B-malignancy-type
)	O
are	O
neural	O

cell	O

derived	O

and	O
rarely	O
occur	O
in	O

gland	O
.	O

are	O
presently	O
no	O

can	O
reliably	O
distinguish	O
benign	O

malignant	O

tumors	I-malignancy-type
.	O

.	O

:	O

:	O

(	O

.	O

,	O
U.S.A	O
.	O
Neuroblastomas	B-malignancy-type
demonstrate	O
both	O
clinical	O
and	O
biological	O
heterogeneity	O
.	O
We	O
have	O
proposed	O
that	O
neuroblastomas	B-malignancy-type
may	O
be	O
classified	O
in	O
three	O
genetically	O
distinct	O
subtypes	O
,	O
based	O
on	O
cytogenetic	O
and	O
molecular	O
analysis	O
.	O
The	O
first	O
comprises	O
those	O
with	O
hyperdiploid	O
or	O
triploid	O
modal	O
karyotypes	O
(	O
or	O
compatible	O
DNA	O
content	O
by	O
flow	O
cytometry	O
)	O
,	O
1p	O
LOH	O
and	O
MYCN	O
amplification	O
are	O
absent	O
,	O
and	O
TRKA	O
expression	O
is	O
high	O
.	O
These	O
patients	O
are	O
likely	O
to	O
be	O
infants	O
with	O
low	O
stages	O
of	O
disease	O

stages	O
1	O
,	O
2	O
,	O
or	O
4S	O
by	O
the	O
International	O
Neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
Staging	O
System	O
)	O
,	O
and	O
they	O
have	O
a	O
very	O
favourable	O
outcome	O
(	O
>	O
90	O
%	O
cure	O
)	O
.	O
The	O
second	O
group	O
consists	O
of	O
tumours	O
that	O
generally	O
have	O
a	O
near	O
diploid	O
or	O
tetraploid	O
modal	O
chromosome	O
number	O
or	O
DNA	O
content	O
but	O
lack	O
MYCN	O
amplification	O
.	O
They	O
usually	O
have	O
1p	O
allelic	O
loss	O
,	O
14q	O
allelic	O
loss	O
or	O
other	O
structural	O
changes	O
,	O
and	O
TRKA	O
expression	O
is	O
usually	O
low	O
.	O
These	O
patients	O
are	O
generally	O
older	O
with	O
advanced	O
stages	O
of	O
disease	O
(	O
stages	O
3	O
or	O
4	O
)	O
,	O
and	O
they	O
have	O
a	O
slowly	O
progressive	O
course	O
,	O
with	O
a	O
cure	O
rate	O
of	O
25-50	O
%	O
.	O
The	O
third	O
group	O
is	O
characterised	O
by	O
tumours	O
with	O
MYCN	O
amplification	O
.	O
These	O
tumours	O
are	O
generally	O
near	O
diploid	O
or	O
tetraploid	O
,	O
with	O
1p	O
allelic	O
loss	O
,	O
and	O
low	O
or	O
absent	O
TRKA	O
expression	O
.	O
The	O
patients	O
are	O
usually	O
between	O
1	O
and	O
5	O
years	O
of	O
age	O
with	O
advanced	O
stages	O
of	O
disease	O
,	O
and	O
they	O
have	O
a	O
very	O
poor	O
prognosis	O
(	O
<	O
5	O
%	O
)	O
.	O
It	O
remains	O
to	O
be	O
determined	O
if	O
tumours	O
in	O
one	O
group	O
ever	O
evolve	O
into	O
a	O
less	O
unfavourable	O
group	O
,	O
but	O
current	O
evidence	O
suggests	O
that	O
they	O
are	O
distinct	O
genetically	O
.	O
The	O
identification	O
of	O
the	O
oncogenes	O
,	O
suppressor	O
genes	O
and	O
growth	O
factor	O
receptor	O
pathways	O
involved	O
in	O
neuroblastomas	B-malignancy-type
has	O
provided	O
great	O
insight	O
into	O
the	O
mechanisms	O
of	O
malignant	O
transformation	O
and	O
progression	O

may	O
provide	O
the	O

for	O
future	O
therapy	O

The	O

and	O
activity	O
of	O

for	O

for	O
cell	O
proliferation	O
)	O

and	O
cell	O
adhesion	O
molecules	O
(	O
for	O
neuronal	O
migration	O
)	O
.	O
One	O
agent	O
,	O
transforming	O
growth	O
factor	O
beta1	O
(	O

)	O

may	O
affect	O
both	O
events	O
.	O

that	O
ethanol	O
alters	O
myriad	O

-	O

activities	O
[	O
i.e.	O
,	O
cell	O
proliferation	O
and	O
neural	O
cell	O
adhesion	O
molecule	O
(	O
N-CAM	O
)	O
expression	O
]	O

B104	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
cells	O

inhibited	O
the	O

of	O
B104	O
cells	O

decreases	O
in	O
cell	O
number	O
and	O
[3H]thymidine	O
(	O
[3H]dT	O
)	O
incorporation	O
.	O

of	O
extracellular	O
signal	O
-	O
regulated	O
kinases	O
(	O

)	O
,	O
which	O
are	O
part	O
of	O
the	O
family	O
of	O
mitogen	O
-	O
activated	O
protein	O
kinases	O
(	O

)	O
.	O

(	O

.	O

and	O
this	O

not	O

by	O
treatment	O
with	O
PD98059	O
.	O
Ethanol	O
inhibited	O
the	O
TGFbeta1	O
-	O
induced	O
up	O
-	O

of	O

in	O

USA	O
.	O
Parathyroid	O
hormone	O
-	O
related	O
protein	O
(	O
PTHrP	O
)	O
was	O
discovered	O
a	O
dozen	O
years	O
ago	O
as	O
a	O
product	O
of	O
malignant	O
tumors	O
.	O
It	O
is	O
now	O
known	O
that	O
PTHrP	O
is	O
a	O
paracrine	O
factor	O
with	O
multiple	O
biological	O
functions	O
.	O
One	O
such	O
function	O
is	O
to	O
relax	O
smooth	O
muscle	O
by	O
inhibiting	O
calcium	O
influx	O
into	O
the	O
cell	O
.	O
In	O
the	O
central	O
nervous	O
system	O
,	O
PTHrP	O
and	O
its	O
receptor	O
are	O
widely	O
expressed	O
in	O
neurons	O
in	O
the	O
cerebral	O
cortex	O
,	O
hippocampus	O
and	O
cerebellum	O
.	O
The	O
function	O
of	O
PTHrP	O
in	O
the	O
CNS	O
is	O
not	O
known	O
.	O
Previous	O
work	O
has	O
shown	O
that	O
expression	O
of	O
the	O
PTHrP	O
gene	O
is	O
depolarization	O
-	O
dependent	O
in	O
cultured	O
cerebellar	O
granule	O
cells	O
and	O
depends	O
specifically	O
on	O
L-type	O
voltage	O
sensitive	O
calcium	O
channel	O
(	O
L-VSCC	O
)	O
Ca(2+)	O
influx	O
.	O
PTHrP	O
has	O
also	O
been	O
found	O
to	O
be	O
capable	O
of	O
protecting	O
these	O
cells	O
against	O
kainic	O
acid	O
-	O
induced	O
excitotoxicity	O
.	O
Here	O
,	O
we	O
tested	O
the	O
idea	O
that	O
mice	O
with	O
a	O
PTHrP	O
-	O
null	O
CNS	O
might	O
display	O
hypersensitivity	O
to	O
kainic	O
acid	O
excitotoxicity	O
.	O
We	O
found	O
that	O
these	O
mice	O
were	O
six	O
-	O
fold	O
more	O
sensitive	O
than	O
control	O
littermate	O
mice	O
to	O
kainic	O
-acid	O
-	O
induced	O
seizures	O
as	O
well	O
as	O
hippocampal	O
c-Fos	O
expression	O
.	O
PTHrP	O
-	O
null	O
embryonic	O
mixed	O
cerebral	O
cortical	O
cultures	O
were	O
more	O
sensitive	O
to	O
kainic	O
acid	O
than	O
control	O
cultures	O
,	O
and	O
PTHrP	O
addition	O
was	O
found	O
to	O
be	O
protective	O
against	O
kainate	O
toxicity	O
in	O
both	O
PTHrP	O
-	O
null	O
and	O
control	O
cultures	O
.	O
By	O
whole	O
-	O
cell	O
techniques	O
,	O
PTHrP	O
was	O
found	O
to	O
reduce	O
L-VSCC	O
Ca(2+)	O
influx	O
in	O
cultured	O
mouse	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
cells	O
.	O
We	O
conclude	O
that	O
PTHrP	O
functions	O
as	O
a	O
component	O
of	O
a	O
neuroprotective	O
feedback	O
loop	O
that	O
is	O
structured	O
around	O
the	O
L-type	O
calcium	O
channel	O
.	O
This	O
loop	O
appears	O
to	O
be	O
operative	O
in	O
vivo	O
as	O
well	O
as	O
in	O
vitro	O
.	O

:	O

.	O
Inclusions	O
containing	O
ubiquitin	O
-	O
protein	O
aggregates	O
appear	O
in	O
neurons	O
of	O
patients	O
with	O
neurodegenerative	O
disorders	O
such	O
as	O
Alzheimer	O
's	O
disease	O
and	O
Parkinson	O
's	O
disease	O
.	O
The	O
relationship	O
between	O
inclusion	O
production	O
and	O
cell	O
viability	O
is	O
not	O
understood	O
.	O
To	O
address	O
this	O
issue	O

we	O
investigated	O
the	O
response	O
of	O
an	O
established	O
mouse	O
neuronal	O
cell	O
line	O
and	O
of	O
embryonic	O
rat	O
mesencephalic	O
cultures	O
to	O
inhibition	O
of	O
the	O
ubiquitin	O
/	O
proteasome	O
pathway	O
.	O
Two	O
proteasome	O
inhibitors	O
,	O
a	O
peptidyl	O
aldehyde	O
and	O
an	O
epoxy	O
ketone	O
,	O
which	O
cause	O
accumulation	O
of	O
ubiquitinated	O
proteins	O

were	O
found	O
to	O
enhance	O
expression	O
of	O
stress	O
-	O
inducible	O
genes	O
,	O
including	O
HSP70i	O
and	O
the	O
polyubiquitin	O
genes	O
UbB	O
and	O
UbC	O
.	O
Under	O
these	O
conditions	O
,	O
mRNA	O
and	O
protein	O
levels	O
of	O
the	O
inducible	O
form	O
of	O
cyclooxygenase	O
(	O
COX-2	O
)	O
were	O
upregulated	O
together	O
with	O
its	O
product	O
,	O
PGE(2)	O
,	O
a	O
proinflammatory	O
prostaglandin	O
.	O
Proteasomal	O
inhibition	O
also	O
led	O
to	O
stabilization	O
of	O
COX-2	O
as	O
ubiquitin	O
conjugates	O
,	O
suggesting	O
that	O
the	O
ubiquitin	O
/	O
proteasome	O
pathway	O
contributes	O
to	O
the	O
regulation	O
of	O
COX-2	O
protein	O
levels	O
.	O
Treatment	O
with	O
antioxidants	O
known	O
to	O
inhibit	O
NFkappaB	O
and	O
AP-1	O
transcriptional	O
activation	O
failed	O
to	O
abrogate	O
COX-2	O
upregulation	O
.	O
Instead	O
,	O
these	O
inhibitors	O
exacerbated	O
the	O
stress	O
response	O
by	O
potentiating	O
HSP70i	O
levels	O
while	O
eliciting	O
a	O
decrease	O
in	O
PGE(2)	O
production	O
.	O
These	O
findings	O
suggest	O
that	O
the	O
accumulation	O
of	O
ubiquitinated	O
proteins	O
resulting	O
from	O
proteasome	O
inhibition	O
in	O
neuronal	O
cells	O
is	O
associated	O
with	O
a	O
proinflammatory	O
response	O
that	O
may	O
be	O
an	O
important	O
contributor	O
to	O
neurodegeneration	O

BACKGROUND	O
:	O
Autologous	O
peripheral	O
blood	O
stem	O
cell	O
(	O
PBSCs	O
)	O
are	O
frequently	O
used	O
to	O
reconstitute	O
hematopoiesis	O
following	O
administration	O
of	O
megatherapy	O
in	O
children	O
with	O
advanced	O
stage	O
IV	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
.	O
Some	O
centers	O
prefer	O
the	O
use	O
of	O
autografts	O
enriched	O
for	O
CD34	O
+	O
progenitor	O
cells	O
because	O
the	O
positive	O
selection	O
procedure	O
is	O
believed	O
to	O
reduce	O
indirectly	O
tumor	O
cell	O
contamination	O
.	O
PROCEDURES	O
:	O
In	O
this	O
study	O
,	O
we	O
monitored	O
the	O
efficiency	O
of	O
tumor	O
cell	O
purging	O
following	O
CD34	O
selection	O
in	O
PBSCs	O
from	O
seven	O
patients	O
with	O
advanced	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
by	O
using	O
a	O
highly	O
sensitive	O
reverse	O
transcriptase	O
-	O
polymerase	O
chain	O
reaction	O
(	O
RT-PCR	O
)	O
analysis	O
,	O
Amplification	O
of	O
tissues	O
-	O
specific	O
mRNA	O
transcript	O
of	O
tyrosine	O
hydroxylase	O
gene	O
with	O
nested	O
primers	O
enabled	O
the	O
detection	O
of	O
residual	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
cells	O
with	O
a	O
sensitivity	O
of	O
one	O
malignant	O
-	O
cell	O
per	O
10(6)	O
normals	O
.	O
RESULTS	O
:	O
Using	O
this	O
method	O
,	O
contaminating	O
tumor	O
cells	O
were	O
detected	O
in	O
seven	O
of	O
nine	O
leukapheresis	O
products	O
of	O
the	O
patients	O
.	O
After	O
positive	O
immunoselection	O
of	O
CD34	O
+	O
cells	O
on	O
Ceprate	O
column	O
,	O
only	O
one	O
of	O
nine	O
enriched	O
stem	O
cell	O
fraction	O
still	O
contained	O
tumor	O
cells	O
detectable	O
by	O
RT-PCR	O
.	O
In	O
six	O
cases	O
,	O
PCR	O
positive	O
PBSCs	O
became	O
PCR	O
negative	O
after	O
selection	O
.	O
CONCLUSIONS	O
:	O
We	O
conclude	O
that	O
tumor	O
cell	O
contamination	O
may	O
be	O
frequently	O
detected	O
in	O
PBSC	O
harvests	O
of	O
stage	O
IV	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
patients	O
by	O
sensitive	O
molecular	O
analysis	O
.	O
The	O
load	O
of	O
contaminating	O
malignant	O
cells	O
might	O
be	O
reduced	O
following	O
CD34	O
selection	O
.	O

:	O

(	O

[	O

Lithium	O
and	O
sodium	O
valproate	O
(	O
VPA	O
)	O
are	O
effective	O
in	O
the	O
treatment	O
of	O
bipolar	O
disorder	O
(	O
BD	O
)	O
and	O
may	O
function	O
through	O
the	O
regulation	O
of	O
signal	O
transduction	O
pathways	O
and	O
transcription	O
factors	O
such	O
as	O
c-	O
fos	O
and	O
c-Jun	O
,	O
which	O
in	O
turn	O
results	O
to	O
changes	O
in	O
gene	O
expression	O
.	O
The	O
long-term	O
efficacy	O
of	O
lithium	O
and	O
VPA	O
in	O
BD	O
suggests	O
that	O
the	O
regulation	O
of	O
gene	O
expression	O
may	O
be	O
an	O
important	O
target	O
for	O
these	O
drugs	O
.	O
Preliminary	O
evidence	O
suggests	O
that	O
c-	O
fos	O
levels	O
and	O
AP-1	O
binding	O
may	O
be	O
regulated	O
by	O
lithium	O
and	O
VPA	O
,	O
but	O
the	O
results	O
are	O
inconclusive	O
.	O
In	O
the	O
present	O
study	O
,	O
we	O
report	O
differential	O
effects	O
of	O
the	O
two	O
most	O
commonly	O
prescribed	O
mood	O
stabilizers	O
used	O
to	O
treat	O
BD	O
on	O
Fos	O
/	O
Jun	O
protein	O
levels	O
and	O
their	O
AP-1	O
binding	O
activity	O
in	O
human	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
SH-SY5Y	O
cells	O
.	O
At	O
therapeutically	O
relevant	O
concentrations	O
,	O
both	O
drugs	O
acutely	O
(	O
<24	O
h	O
)	O
induced	O
c-Fos	O
immunoreactivity	O
and	O
AP-1	O
binding	O
.	O
In	O
contrast	O
to	O
lithium	O
,	O
chronic	O
(	O
1	O
week	O
)	O
treatment	O
with	O
VPA	O
led	O
to	O
continued	O
induction	O
of	O
c-Fos	O
,	O
in	O
addition	O
to	O
induction	O
of	O
c-Jun	O
immunoreactivity	O
and	O
a	O
33	O

kDa	O
band	O
previously	O
identified	O
as	O
chronic	O

.	O

was	O
also	O
increased	O
after	O
1	O
week	O
VPA	O
treatment	O
.	O
These	O
findings	O
suggest	O
that	O
both	O

mood	O
stabilizers	O
may	O
have	O
an	O
effect	O
on	O
neuronal	O

expression	O
of	O
target	O
genes	O
containing	O
the	O
AP-1	O
consensus	O

their	O

acute	O

.	O

Normalization	O
and	O
analysis	O
of	O
cDNA	O
microarrays	O
using	O
within	O
-array	O
replications	O
applied	O
to	O

cell	O
response	O
to	O
a	O

.	O
Fan	O
J,	O
Tam	O
P,	O
Woude	O
GV	O
,	O
Ren	O
Y	O
.	O
Department	O
of	O
Operation	O
Research	O
and	O
Financial	O
Engineering	O
,	O
Princeton	O
University	O

Princeton	O

08544	O
,	O
USA	O
.	O
The	O
quantitative	O
comparison	O
of	O
two	O
or	O
more	O
microarrays	O
can	O
reveal	O
,	O
for	O
example	O
,	O
the	O
distinct	O
patterns	O
of	O
gene	O
expression	O
that	O
define	O
different	O
cellular	O
phenotypes	O
or	O
the	O
genes	O
that	O
are	O
induced	O
in	O
the	O
cellular	O
response	O
to	O
certain	O
stimulations	O
.	O
Normalization	O
of	O
the	O
measured	O
intensities	O
is	O
a	O
prerequisite	O
of	O
such	O
comparisons	O
.	O
However	O
,	O
a	O
fundamental	O
problem	O
in	O
cDNA	O
microarray	O
analysis	O
is	O
the	O
lack	O
of	O
a	O
common	O
standard	O
to	O
compare	O
the	O
expression	O
levels	O
of	O
different	O
samples	O
.	O
Several	O
normalization	O
protocols	O
have	O
been	O
proposed	O
to	O
overcome	O
the	O
variabilities	O
inherent	O
in	O
this	O
technology	O
.	O
We	O
have	O
developed	O
a	O
normalization	O
procedure	O
based	O
on	O
within	O
-array	O
replications	O
via	O
a	O
semilinear	O
in	O
-	O
slide	O
model	O
,	O
which	O
adjusts	O
objectively	O
experimental	O
variations	O
without	O
making	O
critical	O
biological	O
assumptions	O
.	O
The	O
significant	O
analysis	O
of	O
gene	O
expressions	O
is	O
based	O
on	O
a	O
weighted	O
t	O
statistic	O
,	O
which	O
accounts	O
for	O
the	O
heteroscedasticity	O
of	O
the	O
observed	O
log	O
ratios	O
of	O
expressions	O
,	O
and	O
a	O
balanced	O
sign	O
permutation	O
test	O
.	O
We	O
illustrated	O
the	O
use	O
of	O
the	O
techniques	O
in	O
a	O
comparison	O
of	O
the	O
expression	O
profiles	O
of	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
cells	O
that	O
were	O
stimulated	O
with	O
a	O
growth	O
factor	O
,	O
macrophage	O
migration	O
inhibitory	O
factor	O
(	O
MIF	O
)	O
.	O
The	O
analysis	O
of	O
expression	O
changes	O
at	O
mRNA	O
levels	O
showed	O
that	O
approximately	O
99	O
genes	O
were	O
up	O
-	O
regulated	O
and	O
24	O
were	O
reduced	O
significantly	O
(	O
P	O
<0.001	O
)	O
in	O
MIF	O
-	O
stimulated	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
cells	O
.	O
The	O
regulated	O
genes	O
included	O
several	O
oncogenes	O
,	O
growth	O
-	O
related	O
genes	O
,	O
tumor	O
metastatic	O
genes	O
,	O
and	O
immuno	O
-	O
related	O
genes	O
.	O
The	O
findings	O
provide	O
clues	O
as	O
to	O
the	O
molecular	O
mechanisms	O
of	O
MIF	O
-	O
mediated	O
tumor	O
progression	O
and	O
supply	O
therapeutic	O
targets	O
for	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
treatment	O
.	O
PMID	O
:	O
14739336	O
[	O
PubMed	O
-	O
in	O
process	O
]	O

Cancer	O

BACKGROUND	O
:	O
Angiogenesis	O
is	O
essential	O
for	O
tumor	O
growth	O
and	O
relies	O
on	O
the	O
production	O
of	O
angiogenic	O
factors	O
.	O
Vascular	O
endothelial	O
growth	O
factor	O
(	O

)	O
is	O
a	O
major	O
regulator	O
of	O
angiogenesis	O
that	O
binds	O
to	O
tyrosine	O
kinase	O
receptors	O

and	O

of	O

and	O

at	O
gene	O
and	O

levels	O
in	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
remains	O
widely	O
unknown	O
.	O

BACKGROUND	O
AND	O
METHODS	O
.	O
Multidrug	O
resistance	O
in	O
chemotherapy	O
for	O
cancer	O
is	O
characterized	O
by	O
increased	O
genetic	O
expression	O
of	O
P-glycoprotein	O
,	O
which	O
acts	O
as	O
an	O
ATP	O
-	O
dependent	O
drug	O
-	O
efflux	O
pump	O
.	O
To	O
determine	O
whether	O
P-glycoprotein	O
levels	O
are	O
of	O
prognostic	O
value	O
in	O
such	O
cases	O
,	O
we	O
measured	O
these	O
levels	O
immunohistochemically	O
in	O
a	O
retrospective	O
study	O
of	O
sequential	O
tumor	O
samples	O
from	O
67	O
children	O
with	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
.	O
RESULTS	O
.	O

was	O
not	O
detected	O
in	O
pretreatment	O
samples	O
from	O
either	O
of	O
the	O
2	O

with	O

,	O

of	O

it	O
was	O

6	O

.	O

hybrid	O
cells	O

.	O

.	O

decreased	O

of	O

120	O

.	O

described	O
as	O
a	O
-	O

of	O
the	O
tau(-1)	O
(	O

2.1	O

the	O
peak	O

.	O

of	O

.	O

:	O

a	O

with	O
potent	O

.	O

:	O

.	O

Prevention	O
of	O
neocarzinostatin	O

to	O

factor	O
.	O
Falcione	O

Milligan	O
KD	O
,	O

.	O
Neocarzinostatin	O
is	O
an	O
antineoplastic	O
agent	O
that	O
induces	O
differentiated	O
morphology	O
in	O
human	O
(	O
SK	O
-	O
N	O
-	O
SH	O
)	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
cells	O
in	O
culture	O
.	O
We	O
have	O
compared	O
this	O
morphological	O
differentiation	O
with	O
that	O
induced	O
by	O
the	O
endogenous	O
differentiation	O
inducer	O
,	O
nerve	O
growth	O
factor	O
(	O
NGF	O
)	O
,	O
and	O
have	O
explored	O
the	O
effects	O
of	O
exposure	O
to	O
NGF	O
upon	O
the	O
morphological	O
changes	O
induced	O
by	O
neocarzinostatin	O
in	O
SK	O
-	O
N	O
-	O
SH	O
cells	O
.	O
Both	O
NGF	O
and	O
neocarzinostatin	O
induced	O
process	O
outgrowth	O
in	O
these	O
cells	O
.	O
The	O
processes	O
formed	O
in	O
the	O
presence	O
of	O
NGF	O
however	O
,	O
were	O
shorter	O
and	O
thinner	O
than	O
those	O
induced	O
by	O
neocarzinostatin	O
.	O
Furthermore	O
,	O
only	O
neocarzinostatin	O
induced	O
enlargement	O
of	O
the	O
somata	O
of	O
the	O
cells	O
,	O
and	O
caused	O
cell	O
death	O
in	O
a	O
concentration	O
-	O
dependent	O
fraction	O
of	O
the	O
culture	O
.	O
These	O
distinguishing	O
features	O
of	O
treated	O
cells	O
allowed	O
us	O
to	O
determine	O
whether	O
or	O
not	O
NGF	O
exposure	O
altered	O
responsiveness	O
of	O
the	O
cells	O
to	O
neocarzinostatin	O
.	O
NGF	O
(	O
100	O
-	O
1000	O
ng	O
/	O
mL	O
)	O
protected	O
SK	O
-	O
N	O
-	O
SH	O
cells	O
from	O
the	O
morphological	O
and	O
cytocidal	O
effects	O
of	O
neocarzinostatin	O
(	O
1	O
-	O
hr	O
exposure	O
,	O
0.017	O
to	O
0.033	O
micrograms	O
/	O
mL	O
)	O
.	O
Protection	O
from	O
neocarzinostatin	O
required	O
that	O
NGF	O
be	O
continuously	O
present	O
for	O
a	O
period	O
beginning	O
24	O
hr	O
prior	O
to	O
neocarzinostatin	O
exposure	O
and	O
continuing	O
for	O
the	O
duration	O
of	O
the	O
experiment	O
,	O
implying	O
that	O
the	O
protection	O
afforded	O
by	O
NGF	O
has	O
a	O
latency	O
necessitating	O
pretreatment	O
,	O
and	O
is	O
reversible	O
.	O
These	O
results	O
suggest	O
that	O
neocarzinostatin	O
is	O
taken	O
up	O
by	O
the	O
cells	O
and	O
can	O
exert	O
its	O
effects	O
once	O
NGF	O
is	O
removed	O
,	O
even	O
after	O
neocarzinostatin	O
is	O
washed	O
out	O
of	O
the	O
medium	O
.	O
The	O
signal	O
transduction	O
cascade	O
triggered	O
by	O
NGF	O
receptor	O
binding	O
may	O
prevent	O
the	O
action	O

neocarzinostatin	O
or	O

expression	O

1	O
.	O
Cyclophilin	O
A	O
(	O
CyP-A	O
)	O
,	O
a	O
soluble	O
cytoplasmic	O
immunophilin	O
,	O
is	O
known	O
for	O
its	O
involvement	O
in	O
T	O
cell	O
differentiation	O
and	O
proliferation	O
.	O
Although	O
CyP-	O

has	O
a	O
pivotal	O
role	O
in	O
the	O
immune	O
response	O
,	O

is	O
most	O
highly	O
concentrated	O
in	O
brain	O

where	O
its	O
functions	O
are	O
largely	O
unknown	O
.	O
2.	O
We	O
reported	O
previously	O
that	O
a	O

(	O

)	O

1061	O

.	O

The	O
p53	O
gene	O
is	O
the	O
most	O

mutated	O
gene	O
in	O
human	O
cancer	O
.	O

p63	O
and	O
p73	O

revealed	O
that	O
p53	O
is	O
a	O
member	O
of	O
a	O
family	O
of	O
related	O
transcription	O
factors	O

that	O
they	O
share	O
amino	O
acid	O
sequence	O
identity	O

%	O
in	O
the	O

-	O

domain	O
,	O

and	O

gene	O

can	O

and	O

are	O
both	O

DNA	O
damage	O

.	O

suggests	O
that	O

and	O

are	O
important	O
for	O

of	O

development	O
.	O

)	O

member	O

-	O

(	O

)	O
a	O

ago	O
generated	O

for	O

as	O
a	O

transduction	O

of	O
TRAIL	O
-	O
induced	O

have	O
been	O
identified	O
in	O
TRAIL	O
resistant	O
cancer	O
cells	O
.	O

is	O
the	O
most	O
common	O
extracranial	B-malignancy-type
solid	I-malignancy-type
tumor	I-malignancy-type
in	O
children	O
and	O

to	O

of	O

gene	O
.	O

(	O

8	O
expression	O
in	O

lines	O
regardless	O
of	O

:	O

.	O

neuroblastomas	B-malignancy-type
.	O
These	O
tumors	O
might	O
ultimately	O
be	O
distinguished	O

the	O

of	O

of	O

within	O
this	O

of	O
a	O

and	O
complex	O

in	O

one	O

(	O

and	O

cord	O
.	O
The	O
rat	O

,	O

,	O

and	O

of	O

in	O

cell	O

and	O

.	O

.	O
Alpha-synuclein	O
up-regulates	O
expression	O
of	O
caveolin-1	O
and	O
down-regulates	O
extracellular	O
signal-regulated	O

in	O
B103	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
cells	O
:	O
role	O
in	O
the	O
pathogenesis	O
of	O
Parkinson's	O
disease	O
.	O
Hashimoto	O
M	O
,	O
Takenouchi	O
T	O
,	O
Rockenstein	O
E	O
,	O
Masliah	O
E	O
.	O
Department	O
of	O
Neuroscience	O
,	O
University	O
of	O
California	O
at	O
San	O
Diego	O
,	O
La	O
Jolla	O
,	O
California	O
92093-0624	O
,	O
USA	O
.	O
alpha-Synuclein	O
accumulation	O
plays	O
an	O
important	O
role	O
in	O
the	O
pathogenesis	O
of	O
Lewy	O
body	O
disease	O
(	O
LBD	O
)	O
and	O
Parkinson's	O
disease	O
(	O
PD	O
)	O
.	O
Although	O
the	O
mechanisms	O
are	O
not	O
yet	O
clear	O
,	O
it	O
is	O
possible	O
that	O
dysregulation	O
of	O
the	O
extracellular	O
signal-regulated	O
kinase	O
(	O
ERK	O
)	O
might	O
play	O
a	O
role	O
.	O
As	O
caveolins	O
form	O
scaffolds	O
onto	O
which	O
signaling	O
molecules	O
such	O
as	O
ERK	O
can	O
assemble	O
,	O
we	O
propose	O
that	O
signaling	O
alterations	O
associated	O
with	O
alpha-synuclein	O
accumulation	O
and	O
neurodegeneration	O
,	O
might	O
be	O
mediated	O
via	O
caveolae	O
.	O
Therefore	O
,	O
the	O
objective	O
of	O
the	O
present	O
study	O
was	O
to	O
investigate	O
the	O
potential	O
contribution	O
of	O
alterations	O
in	O
the	O
caveolar	O
system	O
in	O
mediating	O
alpha-synuclein	O
effects	O
on	O
the	O
ERK	O
signaling	O
pathway	O
.	O
For	O
this	O
,	O
synuclein	O
-	O
transfected	O
B103	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
cells	O
were	O
used	O
as	O
a	O
model	O
system	O
.	O
In	O
this	O
cell	O
line	O
,	O
caveolin-1	O
expression	O
was	O
up-regulated	O
,	O
whereas	O
,	O
ERK	O
was	O
down-regulated	O
.	O
ERK	O
was	O
weakly	O
but	O
consistently	O
co-immunoprecipitated	O
with	O
alpha-synuclein	O
but	O
caveolin-1	O
did	O
not	O
co-immunoprecipitate	O
with	O
alpha-synuclein	O
.	O
Moreover	O
,	O
treatment	O
of	O
alpha-synuclein	O
-	O
overexpressing	O
cells	O
with	O
caveolin-1	O
antisense	O
oligonucleotides	O
resulted	O
in	O
stimulation	O
of	O
ERK	O
activity	O
,	O
with	O
amelioration	O
of	O
the	O
neuritic	O
alterations	O
.	O
Transduction	O
of	O
alpha-synuclein	O
-overexpressing	O
cells	O
,	O
with	O
an	O
adenoviral	O
vector	O
directing	O
the	O
expression	O
of	O
ERK	O
,	O
resulted	O
in	O
suppression	O
of	O
caveolin-1	O
expression	O
and	O
re-establishment	O
of	O
the	O
normal	O
patterns	O
of	O
neurite	O
outgrowth	O
.	O
These	O
results	O
suggest	O
that	O
alpha-synuclein	O
may	O
also	O
interfere	O
with	O
ERK	O
signaling	O
by	O
dysregulating	O
caveolin-1	O
expression	O
.	O
Thus	O
,	O
the	O
caveolin-1	O
/	O
ERK	O
pathway	O
could	O
be	O
a	O
therapeutic	O
target	O
for	O
the	O

related	O
neurodegenerative	O
disorders	O
.	O

PAINT	O
:	O
a	O

analysis	O
and	O

network	O

tool	O
for	O

.	O
Vadigepalli	O
R	O
,	O
Chakravarthula	O
P	O
,	O
Zak	O
DE	O
,	O

.	O
Baugh	O
Institute	O
for	O

Genomics	O
and	O

.	O
We	O
have	O
developed	O
a	O
bioinformatics	O
tool	O
named	O
PAINT	O
that	O
automates	O
the	O
promoter	O
analysis	O
of	O
a	O
given	O
set	O
of	O
genes	O
for	O
the	O
presence	O
of	O
transcription	O
factor	O
binding	O
sites	O
.	O
Based	O
on	O
coincidence	O
of	O
regulatory	O
sites	O
,	O
this	O
tool	O
produces	O
an	O
interaction	O
matrix	O
that	O
represents	O
a	O
candidate	O
transcriptional	O
regulatory	O
network	O
.	O
This	O
tool	O
currently	O
consists	O
of	O
(	O
1	O
)	O
a	O

of	O
promoter	O
sequences	O
of	O

in	O

various	O
modules	O
that	O
can	O

of	O

candidate	O

.	O

Proteasome	O
activity	O
is	O
essential	O
during	O
cAMP	O
-	O
induced	O
terminal	O
differentiation	O
of	O
a	O
murine	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
cell	O
line	O
(	O
NBP2	O
)	O
.	O
However	O
,	O
the	O
mechanisms	O
through	O
which	O
proteasome	O
affects	O
NBP2	O
differentiation	O
have	O
not	O
been	O
characterized	O
.	O
We	O
hypothesized	O
that	O
proteasome	O
is	O
required	O
to	O
implement	O
the	O
differentiation	O
-	O
mediated	O
effects	O
on	O
cell	O
cycle	O
,	O
and	O
its	O
partial	O
inhibition	O
during	O
differentiation	O
may	O
have	O
adverse	O
consequences	O
.	O
Here	O
we	O
show	O
that	O
partial	O
inhibition	O
of	O
proteasome	O
during	O
cAMP	O
-	O
induced	O
differentiation	O
of	O
NBP2	O
cells	O
causes	O
apoptosis	O
.	O
Whereas	O
differentiation	O
induced	O
growth	O
arrest	O
at	O
G1	O
phase	O
,	O
partial	O
proteasome	O
inhibition	O
during	O
differentiation	O
resulted	O
in	O
the	O
accumulation	O
of	O
cells	O
at	O
G2M	O
phase	O
.	O
Cell	O
cycle	O
data	O
correlated	O
with	O
the	O
level	O
of	O
cyclin	O
-	O
dependent	O
kinase	O
inhibitors	O
p21WAF	O
and	O
p27Kip1	O
,	O
and	O
cyclin	O
A	O
.	O
While	O
the	O
level	O
of	O
p21	O
and	O
p27	O
increased	O
,	O
the	O
level	O
of	O
cyclin	O
A	O
decreased	O
upon	O
differentiation	O
.	O
In	O
contrast	O
,	O
cells	O
treated	O
with	O
proteasome	O
inhibitor	O
in	O
the	O
presence	O
of	O
cAMP	O
-	O
inducing	O
agents	O
showed	O
increased	O
levels	O
of	O
p21	O
and	O
cyclin	O
A	O
early	O
in	O
the	O
course	O
of	O
differentiation	O
.	O
However	O
,	O
the	O
level	O
of	O
p21	O
and	O
p27	O
,	O
but	O
not	O
cyclin	O
A	O
,	O
decreased	O
later	O
during	O
concomitant	O
differentiation	O
and	O
partial	O
proteasome	O
inhibition	O
when	O
cells	O
were	O
undergoing	O
apoptosis	O
.	O
Our	O
data	O
suggest	O
that	O
differentiation	O
-	O
mediated	O
growth	O
arrest	O
is	O
dependent	O
on	O
the	O
temporal	O
activity	O
of	O
cell	O
cycle	O
proteins	O
.	O
Partial	O
inhibition	O
of	O
proteasome	O
interferes	O
with	O
differentiation	O
events	O
partly	O
by	O
stabilizing	O
cell	O
cycle	O
proteins	O
and	O
this	O
triggers	O
apoptosis	O
.	O
Thus	O
,	O
differentiating	O
drugs	O
combined	O
with	O
partial	O
proteasome	O
inhibition	O
may	O
impart	O
higher	O
therapeutic	O
efficacy	O
than	O
differentiating	O
agents	O
alone	O
for	O
the	O
treatment	O
of	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
tumors	O
.	O

Intracellular	O
cyclic	O
AMP	O

of	O

,	O

.	O
We	O
have	O
directly	O
evaluated	O
the	O
effects	O
of	O
various	O
intracellular	O
second	O
messengers	O
including	O
cyclic	O
nucleotides	O
,	O
calcium	O
ion	O
,	O
and	O
inositol	O
polyphosphates	O
on	O
shape	O
and	O
motility	O
of	O
differentiating	O
mouse	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
cells	O
.	O
The	O
messengers	O
were	O
microinjected	O
into	O
cells	O
and	O
the	O
responses	O
of	O
the	O
soma	O
,	O
neurite	O
,	O
and	O
growth	O
cone	O
were	O
monitored	O
using	O
time	O
-	O
lapse	O
video	O
microscopy	O
.	O
Each	O
messenger	O
altered	O
cell	O
shape	O
and	O
motility	O
in	O
a	O
characteristic	O
manner	O
.	O
Cyclic	O
AMP	O
promoted	O
lamellipodial	O
expansion	O
,	O
neurite	O
outgrowth	O
,	O
and	O
motility	O
.	O
The	O
other	O
injected	O
messengers	O
opposed	O
motility	O
.	O
Cyclic	O
GMP	O
caused	O
motile	O
structures	O
to	O
freeze	O
and	O
to	O
retract	O
permanently	O
,	O
while	O
the	O
inhibitory	O
effects	O
of	O
calcium	O
injection	O
were	O
concentration	O
-	O
dependent	O
.	O
Small	O
calcium	O
injections	O
affected	O
specifically	O
actin	O
-	O
containing	O
motile	O
structures	O
which	O
froze	O
and	O
retracted	O
temporarily	O
.	O
Intermediate	O
calcium	O
injections	O
caused	O
a	O
strong	O
contraction	O
at	O
the	O
site	O
of	O
injection	O
in	O
all	O
cells	O
.	O
With	O
large	O
injections	O
,	O
cells	O
retracted	O
long	O
neurites	O
,	O
rounded	O
up	O
,	O
and	O
frequently	O
began	O
vigorous	O
blebbing	O
that	O
continued	O
to	O
cell	O
death	O
.	O
Injections	O
of	O
the	O
inositol	O
polyphosphates	O
IP3(1,4,5)	O
and	O
IP4(1,4,5,6)	O
mimicked	O
the	O
effects	O
of	O
small	O
calcium	O
injections	O
,	O
as	O
did	O
electrical	O
stimulation	O
that	O
elicited	O
action	O
potentials	O
.	O
The	O
results	O
suggest	O
that	O
in	O
mouse	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
cells	O
,	O
intracellular	O
cAMP	O
elevation	O
increases	O
cytoskeletal	O
organization	O
and	O
promotes	O
neurite	O
extension	O
perhaps	O
through	O
an	O
enhancement	O
of	O
cell	O
-	O
substratum	O
adhesion	O
.	O
On	O
the	O
other	O
hand	O
,	O
a	O
rise	O
of	O
intracellular	O
cGMP	O
or	O
intracellular	O
calcium	O
interferes	O
directly	O
with	O
the	O
function	O
and	O

of	O
the	O
actin	O
-	O
microfilament	O
system	O
.	O

of	O

cyclic	O
[3H]AMP	O
was	O
correspondingly	O
less	O
.	O
The	O
electrophoretic	O
characteristics	O
of	O
cyclic	O
AMP	O
-binding	O
proteins	O
of	O
differentiated	O
and	O
malignant	O
cells	O
were	O
identical	O
.	O
There	O
were	O
two	O
binding	O
peaks	O
,	O
but	O
the	O
extent	O
of	O
binding	O
at	O
each	O
peak	O
was	O
relatively	O
high	O
in	O
differentiated	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
cells	O
.	O
An	O
increase	O
in	O
cyclic	O
AMP	O
binding	O
occurred	O
24	O
hr	O
after	O
treatment	O
of	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
cells	O
with	O
prostaglandin	O
E1	O
.	O
This	O
increase	O
was	O
completely	O
blocked	O
by	O
cycloheximide	O
but	O
not	O
by	O
actinomycin	O
D	O
.	O
The	O
binding	O
was	O
heat	O
labile	O
and	O
sensitive	O
to	O
protease	O
action	O
.	O
These	O
data	O
indicate	O
that	O
the	O
increase	O
in	O
binding	O
in	O
differentiated	O
cells	O
is	O
due	O
to	O
an	O
elevation	O
in	O
the	O
levels	O
of	O
binding	O
proteins	O
.	O
The	O
binding	O
of	O
cyclic	O
AMP	O
with	O
soluble	O
proteins	O
from	O
rat	O
glial	O
cells	O
and	O
mouse	O
L-cells	O
did	O
not	O
significantly	O
change	O
after	O
treatment	O
with	O
prostaglandin	O
E1	O
or	O
an	O
inhibitor	O
of	O
cyclic	O
AMP	O
phosphodiesterase	O
.	O

and	O
guanosine	O

the	O

proteins	O

about	O

does	O

CpG	O

hypermethylation	O
of	O
gene	O
promoters	O
is	O
a	O
frequent	O
mechanism	O
for	O
gene	O
inactivation	O
in	O
tumors	O
.	O
Many	O
neuroblastomas	B-malignancy-type
have	O
hypermethylation	O
and	O
down	O
-	O
regulation	O
of	O
CASP8	O
,	O
leading	O
to	O
resistance	O
to	O
tumor	O
necrosis	O
factor	O
-	O
related	O
apoptosis	O
-	O
inducing	O
ligand	O
(	O
TRAIL	O
)	O
.	O
We	O
recently	O
found	O
hypermethylation	O
of	O
the	O
four	O
TRAIL	O
receptors	O
in	O
9	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
cell	O
lines	O
.	O
Here	O
,	O
we	O
analyzed	O
methylation	O
of	O
34	O
genes	O
in	O
22	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
cell	O
lines	O
.	O
Of	O
the	O
29	O
newly	O
analyzed	O
genes	O
,	O
only	O
FLIP	O
at	O
chromosome	O
band	O
2q33	O
was	O
methylated	O
in	O
8	O
/	O
22	O
cell	O
lines	O
.	O
The	O
FLIP	O
protein	O
is	O
a	O
negative	O
regulator	O
of	O
Caspase	O
8	O
.	O
FLIP	O
maps	O
adjacent	O
to	O
CASP8	O
,	O
and	O
their	O
methylation	O
patterns	O
showed	O
a	O
moderate	O
correlation	O
.	O
Furthermore	O
,	O
co	O
-	O
methylation	O
patterns	O
were	O
observed	O
for	O
the	O
TRAIL	O
receptor	O

and	O
DCR2	O
and	O
between	O
DR4	O
and	O
DR5	O
.	O
All	O
four	O
receptors	O
co	O
-	O
localize	O
in	O
chromosome	O
band	O
8p21	O
.	O
The	O

genes	O
methylated	O
in	O
neuroblastomas	B-malignancy-type
appeared	O
to	O
occur	O
in	O
pairs	O
.	O
The	O
genes	O
within	O
each	O
pair	O
have	O
a	O
strong	O
sequence	O
homology	O
and	O
originated	O
from	O
gene	O
duplication	O
.	O
We	O
found	O
no	O
evidence	O
for	O

of	O

given	O

in	O
additional	O
local	O
CpG	O
islands	O
.	O

gene	O

showed	O
a	O

co	O
-	O
regulation	O
at	O
the	O
mRNA	O
expression	O

of	O

down	O
-	O
regulation	O
of	O

and	O
this	O
was	O

for	O

and	O

of	O
the	O
down	O

genes	O
was	O

.	O
This	O
suggests	O
a	O

of	O
co	O
-	O
regulated	O

of	O

gene	O

is	O
less	O

.	O

.	O

methylated	O

BACKGROUND	O
:	O

is	O
no	O

by	O

agents	O

METHODS	O
:	O

transcriptional	O
changes	O
induced	O
in	O
rat	O

cells	O

)	O

using	O

arrays	O
.	O

large	O
sample	O
size	O
was	O
used	O
(	O
total	O
of	O
16	O
arrays	O
)	O
.	O
Genes	O
were	O
ranked	O
by	O
P-value	O
(	O
t-test	O
)	O
.	O
RT-PCR	O
was	O
used	O
to	O
confirm	O
(	O
or	O
reject	O
)	O
the	O
expression	O
changes	O
of	O
several	O
of	O
the	O
genes	O
with	O
the	O
lowest	O
P-values	O
.	O
Different	O
P-value	O
filtering	O
methods	O
were	O
compared	O
in	O
terms	O
of	O
their	O
ability	O
to	O
detect	O
these	O
differentially	O
expressed	O
genes	O
.	O
A	O
retrospective	O
power	O
analysis	O
was	O
then	O
performed	O
to	O
determine	O
whether	O
the	O
use	O
of	O
lower	O
sample	O
sizes	O
might	O
also	O
have	O
detected	O
those	O
genes	O
with	O
altered	O
transcription	O
.	O
RESULTS	O
:	O
Based	O
on	O
RT-PCR	O
,	O
mefloquine	O
upregulated	O
cJun	O
,	O
IkappaB	O
and	O
GADD153	O
.	O
Reverse	O
Holm-Bonferroni	O
P-value	O
filtering	O
was	O
superior	O
to	O
other	O
methods	O
in	O
terms	O
of	O
maximizing	O
detection	O
of	O
differentially	O
expressed	O
genes	O
but	O
not	O
those	O
with	O
unaltered	O
expression	O
.	O
Reduction	O
of	O
total	O
microarray	O
sample	O
size	O
(	O
<	O
10	O
)	O
impaired	O
the	O
capacity	O
to	O
detect	O
differentially	O
expressed	O
genes	O
.	O
CONCLUSIONS	O
:	O
Adequate	O
sample	O
sizes	O
and	O
appropriate	O
selection	O
of	O
P-value	O
filtering	O
methods	O
are	O
essential	O
for	O
the	O
reliable	O
detection	O
of	O
differentially	O
expressed	O
genes	O
.	O
The	O
changes	O
in	O
gene	O
expression	O
induced	O
by	O
mefloquine	O
suggest	O
that	O
the	O
ER	O
might	O
be	O
a	O
neuronal	O
target	O
of	O
the	O
drug	O
.	O

:	O

(	O

)	O

298-302	O
.	O
Microarray-analysis	O
:	O
a	O
new	O
approach	O
to	O
study	O
the	O
molecular	O
mechanisms	O
of	O
thermo-chemotherapy	O
.	O
Schulte	O
JH	O
,	O
Schramm	O
A	O
,	O
Pressel	O
T	O
,	O
Klein-Hitpass	O
L,	O
Kremens	O
B	O
,	O
Eils	O
J,	O
Havers	O
W	O
,	O
Eggert	O
A	O
.	O
University	O
Children	O
's	O
Hospital	O
of	O
Essen	O
,	O
Germany	O
.	O
BACKGROUND	O
:	O
Experimental	O
studies	O
for	O
the	O
treatment	O
of	O
relapsed	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
include	O
the	O
use	O
of	O
hyperthermia	O
in	O
combination	O
with	O
chemotherapeutic	O
drugs	O
.	O
Cytotoxic	O
effects	O
of	O
alkylants	O
and	O
platinum	O
compounds	O
on	O
tumor	O
cells	O
can	O
be	O
enhanced	O
by	O
hyperthermia	O
in	O
various	O
in	O
vitro	O
models	O
.	O
However	O
,	O
the	O
underlying	O
molecular	O
mechanisms	O
are	O
still	O
largely	O
unknown	O
.	O
METHOD	O
:	O
In	O
this	O
study	O
,	O
we	O
used	O
microarray-analysis	O
as	O
a	O
new	O
biological	O
approach	O
to	O
gain	O
insight	O
into	O
the	O
pharmacogenomics	O
and	O
possible	O
target	O
genes	O
of	O
thermochemotherapy	O
.	O
As	O
a	O
model	O
,	O
LAN	O
1	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
cells	O
were	O
treated	O
for	O
1	O
h	O
with	O
low	O
doses	O
of	O
cisplatin	O
alone	O
,	O
with	O
simultaneous	O
heating	O
to	O
42	O
degrees	O
C	O
or	O
with	O
hyperthermia	O
alone	O
.	O
Gene	O
expression	O
was	O
analyzed	O
at	O
five	O
time	O
points	O
0	O
to	O
24	O
h	O
after	O
treatment	O
using	O
U95Av2	O
oligonucleotide	O
arrays	O
(	O
Affymetrix	O
Inc	O
)	O
.	O
Significant	O
changes	O
of	O
gene	O
expression	O
levels	O
were	O
calculated	O
by	O
similarity	O
metrices	O
and	O
Pearson	O
correlation	O
.	O
RESULTS	O
:	O
Only	O
a	O
few	O
genes	O
(	O
n	O
=	O
23	O
)	O
demonstrated	O
altered	O
expression	O
following	O
treatment	O
of	O
LAN	O
1	O
cells	O
with	O
cisplatin	O
alone	O
.	O
Hyperthermia	O
alone	O
resulted	O
in	O
significant	O
expression	O
changes	O
of	O
136	O
genes	O
in	O
comparison	O
to	O
untreated	O
control	O
cells	O
.	O
Combination	O
therapy	O
of	O
cisplatin	O
and	O
hyperthermia	O
resulted	O
in	O
expression	O
changes	O
of	O
251	O
genes	O
,	O
interestingly	O
including	O
131	O
genes	O
with	O
unchanged	O
expression	O
under	O
treatment	O
with	O
either	O
cisplatin	O
or	O
hyperthermia	O
alone	O
.	O
Significant	O
changes	O
of	O
expression	O
levels	O
could	O
be	O
annotated	O
to	O
genes	O
involved	O
in	O
heat	O
shock	O
response	O
,	O
protein	O
degradation	O
and	O
apoptosis	O
.	O
These	O
results	O
are	O
now	O
being	O
validated	O
on	O
mRNA	O
-	O
and	O
protein	O
levels	O
by	O
RT-PCR	O
and	O
Western	O
Blot	O
analysis	O
.	O
CONCLUSION	O
:	O
Microarray-Analysis	O
is	O
a	O
suitable	O
new	O
approach	O
for	O
the	O
identification	O
of	O
target	O
genes	O
,	O
which	O
might	O
play	O
an	O
important	O
role	O
for	O
the	O
synergistic	O
effect	O
of	O
hyperthermia	O
and	O
chemotherapy	O
in	O
tumor	O
cells	O
.	O
PMID	O
:	O
14677092	O
[	O
PubMed	O
-	O
in	O
process	O
]	O

(	O

)	O

transient	O

into	O
NG108-15	O
,	O
NE1	O
-	O
115	O
and	O
COS-1	O
cells	O
.	O
We	O
show	O
that	O
regulation	O
is	O
T3	O
specific	O
as	O
estrogen	O
,	O
dexamethasone	O
,	O
dihydrotestosterone	O
,	O
all-trans	O
-	O
retinoic	O
acid	O
and	O
9-cis	O
-	O
retinoic	O
acid	O
have	O
no	O
effect	O
.	O
We	O
localized	O
several	O
potential	O
T3REs	O
and	O
characterized	O
the	O
most	O

(	O
position	O
3280	O
-	O
3291	O
)	O
which	O
contains	O
two	O
hexameric	O
half	O

arranged	O
as	O
a	O
direct	O
repeat	O
without	O
a	O
base	O
pair	O

.	O
An	O
oligonucleotide	O
containing	O
this	O
sequence	O
confers	O
T3	O
responsiveness	O
to	O
a	O
heterologous	O
promoter	O
.	O
The	O

response	O
of	O
this	O

is	O
markedly	O
reduced	O
after	O
mutation	O
of	O

or	O
second	O
half	O
-site	O
indicating	O
that	O
both	O
half	O

are	O
required	O
for	O
a	O
maximal	O
T3	O
response	O
.	O
We	O
have	O
found	O
that	O

alpha	O
,	O
RXR	O
alpha	O
and	O
COUP-TF	O
do	O
not	O
enhance	O
T3	O
responsiveness	O
and	O
therefore	O

may	O
not	O
interact	O
with	O
T3R	O
alpha	O
in	O
NG108-15	O
cells	O
on	O
this	O
regulatory	O
sequence	O
.	O
T3R	O
monomer	O
and	O
dimer	O
specific	O
binding	O
to	O
the	O
proximal	O
T3RE	O
is	O
demonstrated	O
by	O
gel	O
-	O
retardation	O
DNA	O
binding	O
assays	O
and	O
by	O
methylation	O
interference	O
experiments	O
.	O

.	O

that	O

interactions	O
.	O

brain	O
barrier	O
.	O
Since	O
astrocytes	O
play	O
a	O
central	O
role	O
in	O
establishing	O
this	O
barrier	O
,	O
the	O
authors	O
investigated	O
the	O
hypothesis	O
that	O
the	O
HTLV-	O
I	O
infected	O
T	O
cells	O
disrupt	O
this	O
barrier	O
by	O
damaging	O
the	O
astrocytes	O
.	O
The	O
present	O
study	O
revealed	O
the	O
HTLV-	O
I-	O
producing	O
T	O
cells	O
conferred	O
a	O
severe	O
cytopathic	O
effect	O
upon	O
monolayers	O
of	O
astrocytoma	B-malignancy-type
cell	O
line	O
in	O
co	O
-	O
cultures	O
.	O
Following	O
co	O
-	O
cultivation	O
,	O
HTLV-	O
I	O
DNA	O
and	O
proteins	O
appeared	O
in	O
the	O
monolayer	O
cells	O
,	O
but	O
after	O
reaching	O
a	O
peak	O
their	O
level	O
gradually	O
declined	O
.	O
This	O
appearance	O
of	O
the	O
viral	O
components	O
was	O
proved	O
to	O
result	O
from	O
a	O
fusion	O
of	O
the	O
astrocytic	O
cells	O
with	O
the	O
virus	O
-	O
producing	O
T	O
cells	O
,	O
whereas	O
their	O
subsequent	O
decline	O
reflected	O
the	O
destruction	O
of	O
the	O
resulting	O
syncytia	O
.	O
This	O
fusion	O
could	O
be	O
specifically	O
blocked	O
by	O
anti	O
HTLV-	O
I	O
Env	O
antibodies	O
,	O
indicating	O
that	O
it	O
was	O
mediated	O
by	O
the	O
viral	O
Env	O
proteins	O
expressed	O
on	O
the	O
surface	O
of	O
the	O
virus	O
-	O
producing	O
cells	O
.	O
Similar	O
fusion	O
was	O
observed	O
between	O
the	O
HTLV-	O
I-	O
producing	O
cells	O
and	O
certain	O
other	O
human	O
nervous	O
system	O
cell	O
lines	O
.	O
If	O
such	O
fusion	O
of	O
HTLV-	O
I-	O
infected	O
T	O
cells	O
occurs	O
also	O
with	O
astrocytes	O
and	O
other	O
nervous	O
system	O
cells	O
in	O
TSP/HAM	O
patients	O
,	O
it	O
may	O
account	O
,	O
at	O
least	O
partially	O
,	O
for	O
the	O
blood	O
-	O
brain	O
barrier	O
breakdown	O
and	O
some	O
of	O
the	O
neural	O
lesions	O
in	O
this	O
syndrome	O

CD44	O
gene	O
products	O
are	O
potential	O
markers	O
of	O
aggressiveness	O
in	O
different	O
tumor	O
models	O
,	O

which	O
prompted	O
us	O
to	O
study	O
clinical	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
(	O
NB	B-malignancy-type
)	O
specimens	O
.	O
CD44	O
expression	O
was	O
determined	O
by	O
immunostaining	O
of	O
52	O
NB	B-malignancy-type
with	O
a	O
monoclonal	O
antibody	O
(	O
J173	O
)	O
directed	O
against	O
an	O
epitope	O
common	O
to	O
all	O
CD44	O
isoforms	O
.	O
All	O
tumors	O
were	O
from	O
patients	O
(	O
pts	O
)	O
with	O
newly	O
diagnosed	O
NB	B-malignancy-type
treated	O
with	O
standardized	O
protocols	O
.	O
They	O
were	O
classified	O
according	O
to	O
international	O
criteria	O
[11]	O
.	O
CD44	O
immunoreactivity	O
was	O
detected	O
in	O
37	O
tumors	O
(	O
71	O
%	O
)	O
.	O
CD44	O
was	O
expressed	O
in	O
100	O
%	O
of	O
favorable	O
NB	B-malignancy-type
stages	O
(	O
1	O
,	O
2	O
or	O
4S	O
)	O
,	O
but	O
only	O
50	O
%	O
of	O
advanced	O
NB	B-malignancy-type
(	O
stages	O
3	O
and	O
4	O
)	O
(	O
p	O
=	O
0.0001	O
)	O
,	O
suggesting	O
that	O
the	O
absence	O
rather	O
that	O
the	O
overexpression	O
of	O
CD44	O
is	O
a	O
signal	O
of	O
tumor	O
aggressiveness	O
.	O

cumulative	O
event	O
-	O
free	O
survival	O
was	O
significantly	O
longer	O
in	O
pts	O
with	O
CD44	O
-	O
positive	O
tumors	O
as	O
compared	O
to	O
pts	O
with	O
CD44	O
tumors	O
(	O
p	O
<	O
10(-5	O
)	O
)	O
.	O
More	O
importantly	O
,	O
progression	O
-	O
free	O
survival	O
was	O
also	O
significantly	O
higher	O
in	O
CD44	O
-	O
positive	O
pts	O
within	O
the	O
high	O
-risk	O
group	O
(	O
p	O
<	O
0.01	O
)	O
.	O
In	O
univariate	O
analyses	O
,	O
we	O
tested	O
the	O
prognostic	O
value	O
of	O
tumor	O
expression	O
of	O
CD44	O
in	O
comparison	O
with	O
tumor	O
stage	O

age	O
,	O
tumor	O
histology	O
and	O
presence	O
or	O
absence	O
of	O
N-myc	O
proto	O
-	O
oncogene	O
amplification	O
.	O
All	O
five	O
measures	O
had	O
significant	O
prognostic	O
value	O
.	O
The	O
expression	O
of	O
CD44	O
and	O
the	O
absence	O
of	O
N-myc	O
amplification	O
were	O
the	O
most	O

predictors	O
of	O
a	O
favorable	O
clinical	O
outcome	O
.	O
In	O
a	O
multivariate	O
analysis	O
of	O
these	O
measures	O
,	O
CD44	O
expression	O
and	O
tumor	O
stage	O
were	O
the	O
only	O
independent	O
prognostic	O
factors	O
for	O
the	O
prediction	O
of	O
patient	O
survival	O
.	O
NB	B-malignancy-type
is	O
the	O
first	O
clinical	O
model	O
described	O
in	O
which	O
tumor	O
aggressiveness	O
correlates	O
with	O
a	O

of	O

expression	O
.	O

tumour	O

(	O

of	O

needle	O

(	O

of	O

advanced	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
.	O

through	O
July	O

64	O

any	O

within	O

first	O

.	O

.	O

was	O
2.3x10(6)	O
(	O

analysis	O
was	O

%	O

cells	O
were	O

FNAC	O
of	O
deeply	O
located	O
advanced	O

Genistein	O
modulates	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
cell	O
proliferation	O
and	O
differentiation	O
through	O
induction	O
of	O
apoptosis	O
and	O
regulation	O
of	O
tyrosine	O
kinase	O
activity	O
and	O
N-myc	O
expression	O
.	O
Brown	O
A	O
,	O
Jolly	O
P,	O
Wei	O
H.	O
Department	O
of	O
Environmental	O
Health	O
Sciences	O
,	O
University	O
of	O
Alabama	O
,	O
Birmingham	O
35294	O
,	O
USA	O
.	O
Genistein	O
is	O
a	O
specific	O
inhibitor	O
of	O
protein	O
tyrosine	O
kinase	O
(	O
PTK	O
)	O
and	O
is	O
considered	O
as	O
a	O
therapeutic	O
candidate	O
for	O
various	O
cancers	O
.	O
In	O
this	O
paper	O
we	O
investigate	O
the	O
effects	O
of	O
genistein	O
on	O
cell	O
proliferation	O
and	O
differentiation	O
in	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
(	O
NB	B-malignancy-type
)	O
cell	O
lines	O
and	O
its	O
possible	O
mechanism	O
of	O
action	O
.	O
Genistein	O
substantially	O
inhibited	O
the	O
growth	O
of	O
five	O
(	O
N2A	O
,	O
JC	O
,	O
SKNSH	O
,	O
MSN	O
and	O
Lan5	O
)	O
of	O
the	O
six	O
tumor	O
cell	O
lines	O
examined	O
in	O
a	O
dose	O
-	O
dependent	O
manner	O
with	O
an	O
IC50	O
value	O
of	O
approximately	O
5	O
microg	O
/	O
ml	O
.	O
The	O
exception	O
was	O
GC	O
cells	O
.	O

cells	O
were	O
treated	O
with	O
genistein	O
for	O
6	O
days	O
and	O
exhibited	O
morphological	O
features	O
of	O
differentiation	O
,	O
as	O
evidenced	O
by	O
the	O
development	O
of	O
dendritic	O
extensions	O
.	O
Terminal	O
deoxynucleotidyl	O
transferase	O
(	O
TDT	O
)	O
histochemical	O
staining	O
showed	O
a	O
significant	O
elevation	O
in	O
darkly	O
stained	O
nuclei	O
in	O
genistein	O
-	O
treated	O
N2A	O
cells	O
compared	O
with	O
controls	O
,	O
indicating	O
the	O
occurrence	O
of	O
apoptosis	O
.	O
Fluorescent	O
quantitation	O
of	O
DNA	O
fragments	O
confirmed	O
apoptosis	O
in	O
genistein	O
-	O
treated	O
N2A	O
cells	O
.	O
To	O
further	O
elucidate	O
the	O
possible	O
mechanisms	O
by	O
which	O
genistein	O
modulates	O
NB	B-malignancy-type
cell	O
growth	O
and	O
differentiation	O

investigated	O
the	O
effect	O
of	O

on	O
the	O
activities	O
of	O
PTK	O
and	O
mitogen	O
-	O
activated	O
protein	O
(	O

)	O
kinase	O
and	O

proto	O
-	O
oncogene	O
expression	O
in	O
N2A	O
cells	O
.	O

that	O

activity	O
by	O
approximately	O
33	O
%	O
and	O
inhibited	O

-	O

growth	O
factor	O
(	O

)	O
-	O
stimulated	O
PTK	O
activity	O
by	O
75	O
%	O
.	O

of	O

activity	O

kinase	O
was	O

reduced	O

expression	O

a	O
dose	O

fashion	O
.	O

that	O
genistein	O

and	O

activity	O

-	O
oncogene	O
expression	O
.	O

An	O
attractive	O

to	O

of	O
solid	B-malignancy-type
tumors	I-malignancy-type

agents	O

of	O

than	O

the	O
tumor	O
cells	O
themselves	O
.	O

strategy	O
has	O
3	O

:	O
(	O
a	O
)	O
it	O
should	O
be	O
applicable	O
to	O

types	O
of	O
solid	B-malignancy-type

because	O
all	O
require	O

for	O

and	O
growth	O
;	O

target	O

cells	O
are	O

accessible	O
through	O
the	O

and	O
are	O
normal	O

of	O
resistant	O
mutants	O
unlikely	O
;	O
and	O
(	O

there	O
is	O
an	O
in	O
-	O
built	O
amplification	O
mechanism	O
because	O
thousands	O
of	O
tumor	O

on	O
each	O

for	O

.	O

BACKGROUND	O
:	O
Bovine	O
seminal	O
ribonuclease	O
(	O
BS-RNase	O
)	O
exerts	O
selective	O
cytotoxicity	O
toward	O
different	O
types	O
of	O
tumor	O
cells	O
.	O
In	O
the	O
present	O
study	O
,	O
we	O
tested	O
the	O
effects	O
of	O
BS-RNase	O
on	O
cultured	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
(	O
NB	B-malignancy-type
)	O
cells	O
resistant	O
to	O
chemotherapeutic	O
agents	O
.	O
The	O
selectivity	O
of	O
the	O
antitumoral	O
activity	O
of	O
BS-RNase	O
was	O
evaluated	O
using	O
cultures	O
of	O
CD34	O
+	O
hematopoietic	O
stem	O
cells	O
.	O
MATERIALS	O
AND	O
METHODS	O
:	O
Human	O
NB	B-malignancy-type
cell	O
lines	O
including	O
IMR-32	O
,	O
UKF-NB-2	O
and	O
UKF-NB-3	O
were	O
selected	O
for	O
resistance	O
against	O
vincristine	O
,	O
doxorubicin	O
or	O
cisplatin	O
by	O
exposure	O
to	O
increasing	O
concentrations	O
of	O
the	O
respective	O
drug	O
.	O
The	O
cytotoxicity	O
of	O
the	O
drugs	O
to	O
NB	B-malignancy-type
cells	O
was	O
evaluated	O
using	O
a	O
clonogenic	O
assay	O
in	O
a	O
methylcellulose	O
medium	O
.	O
Peripheral	O
blood	O
progenitor	O
cells	O
were	O
obtained	O
from	O
adult	O
healthy	O
donors	O
by	O
positive	O
selection	O
using	O
specific	O
anti	O
-	O
CD34	O
+	O
antibodies	O
.	O
The	O
toxicity	O
of	O
BS-RNase	O
to	O
CD34	O
+	O
cells	O
was	O
assessed	O
in	O
the	O
direct	O
clonogenic	O
assay	O
using	O
methylcellulose	O
medium	O
or	O
in	O
ex	O
vivo	O
expansion	O
culture	O
supplemented	O
with	O
hematopoietic	O
growth	O
factors	O
.	O
RESULTS	O
:	O
In	O
the	O
clonogenic	O
assay	O
it	O
was	O
shown	O
that	O
BS-RNase	O
completely	O
inhibits	O
growth	O
of	O
both	O
parental	O
NB	B-malignancy-type
cells	O
and	O
their	O
sublines	O
resistant	O
to	O
chemotherapeutic	O
drugs	O
at	O
concentrations	O
(	O
up	O
to	O
50	O
micrograms	O
/	O
ml	O
)	O
which	O
have	O
no	O
significant	O
influence	O
on	O
the	O
growth	O
of	O
colony	O
-	O
forming	O
units	O
,	O
granulocyte	O
macrophage	O
and	O
erythroid	O
burst	O
-	O
forming	O
units	O
.	O
Moreover	O
,	O
BS-RNase	O
had	O
no	O
effect	O
on	O
the	O
ex	O
vivo	O
expansion	O
of	O
total	O
hematopoietic	O
cells	O
or	O
of	O
colony	O
-	O
forming	O
cells	O
from	O
CD34	O
+	O
progenitors	O
.	O
CONCLUSIONS	O
:	O
BS-RNase	O
is	O
a	O
highly	O
efficient	O
agent	O
against	O
NB	B-malignancy-type
cells	O
resistant	O
to	O
chemotherapeutic	O
drugs	O
.	O

of	O

to	O
hematopoietic	O

that	O

to	O
have	O
tolerable	O
hematopoietic	O
toxicity	O
.	O

Infection	O
with	O
human	O
cytomegalovirus	O
(	O
HCMV	O
)	O
is	O
a	O
common	O
and	O
generally	O
asymptomatic	O
affection	O
in	O
childhood	O
.	O
Its	O
role	O
in	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
(	O
NB	B-malignancy-type
)	O
patients	O
has	O
not	O
yet	O
been	O
elucidated	O
.	O
As	O
evidence	O
grows	O
that	O
HCMV	O
interacts	O
with	O
apoptotic	O
signaling	O
due	O
to	O
the	O
interaction	O
of	O
HCMV	O

products	O
with	O
cellular	O
proteins	O
of	O
apoptotic	O
pathways	O
,	O
we	O
used	O
human	O
NB	B-malignancy-type
cell	O
line	O
UKF-NB-2	O
persistently	O
infected	O
with	O
HCMV	O
strain	O
AD169	O
to	O
study	O
the	O
effects	O
of	O
long-term	O
HCMV	O
infection	O
on	O
programmed	O
cell	O
death	O
of	O
neuroectodermal	B-malignancy-type
tumor	I-malignancy-type
cells	O
.	O
The	O
cells	O
designated	O
UKF-NB-	O
2AD169	O
continued	O
to	O
produce	O
infectious	O
virus	O
in	O
successive	O
subcultures	O
over	O
a	O
period	O
of	O
more	O
than	O
1	O
year	O
.	O
Up	O
to	O
20	O
%	O
of	O
cells	O
expressed	O
viral	O
genes	O
or	O
produced	O
infectious	O
virus	O
after	O
initiation	O
of	O
infection	O
.	O
UKF-NB-	O
2AD169	O
cells	O
were	O
significantly	O
less	O
sensitive	O
to	O
the	O
cytotoxic	O
agents	O
cisplatinum	O
and	O
etoposide	O
than	O
parental	O
(	O
noninfected	O
)	O
UKF-NB-2	O
cells	O
.	O
These	O
effects	O
were	O
associated	O
with	O
decreased	O
ability	O
of	O
UKF-NB-	O
2AD169	O
cells	O
to	O
undergo	O
apoptosis	O
and	O
continuous	O
viral	O
replication	O
.	O

cells	O

increased	O
levels	O
of	O
antiapoptosis	O
Bcl-2	O
protein	O
(	O
up	O
to	O
12	O

fold	O

whereas	O
expression	O
of	O
p53	O
and	O
c-myc	O
was	O
not	O
changed	O
.	O

of	O

virus	O
production	O

reestablished	O
sensitivity	O
to	O
chemotherapy	O

lowered	O

expression	O

and	O
facilitated	O
inducibility	O
of	O
apoptosis	O
to	O
the	O
level	O
of	O
the	O
parental	O
cell	O
line	O
.	O
The	O
results	O
demonstrate	O
that	O
persistent	O
HCMV	O
infection	O
confers	O
resistance	O
to	O
cytotoxic	O
agents	O
on	O
neuroectodermal	B-malignancy-type
tumor	I-malignancy-type
cells	O
and	O
protects	O
from	O
apoptosis	O

probably	O
due	O
to	O
increased	O
levels	O
of	O
Bcl-2	O
protein	O
.	O

is	O

that	O

during	O

BACKGROUND	O
:	O
Neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
has	O
several	O
characteristics	O
that	O
suggest	O
that	O
preclinical	O
diagnosis	O
might	O
improve	O
outcome	O
.	O
Therefore	O
,	O
the	O
Quebec	O
Neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
Screening	O
Project	O
was	O
undertaken	O
from	O
1989	O
to	O
1994	O
to	O
examine	O
infants	O
at	O
3	O
weeks	O
and	O
6	O
months	O
by	O
measuring	O
urinary	O
catecholamine	O
metabolites	O
.	O
PROCEDURE	O
:	O
Over	O
the	O
5-yr	O
period	O
,	O
45	O
tumors	O
were	O
detected	O
by	O
screening	O
,	O
20	O
were	O
identified	O
clinically	O
prior	O
to	O
the	O
third	O
week	O
,	O
and	O
64	O
were	O
identified	O
clinically	O
at	O
a	O
later	O
time	O
.	O
We	O
analyzed	O
available	O
tumors	O
for	O
Shimada	O
histopathology	O
,	O
tumor	O
ploidy	O
,	O
MYCN	O
copy	O
number	O
and	O
serum	O
ferritin	O
.	O
RESULTS	O
:	O
Of	O
the	O
tumors	O
detected	O
by	O
screening	O
,	O
only	O
2	O
of	O
45	O
tested	O
had	O
unfavorable	O
histology	O
,	O
2	O
of	O
45	O
had	O
diploid	O
or	O
tetraploid	O
DNA	O
content	O
,	O
0	O
of	O
43	O
had	O
MYCN	O
amplification	O
,	O
and	O
4	O
of	O
44	O
had	O
elevated	O
serum	O
ferritin	O
.	O
All	O
of	O
these	O
patients	O
are	O
alive	O
and	O
well	O
.	O
The	O
20	O
patients	O
detected	O
prior	O
to	O
the	O
3-week	O
screen	O
had	O
similar	O
biological	O
characteristics	O
.	O
In	O
contrast	O
,	O
of	O
the	O
patients	O
detected	O
clinically	O
after	O
3	O
weeks	O
of	O
age	O
,	O
19	O
of	O
51	O
testedhad	O
unfavorable	O
histology	O
,	O
25	O
of	O
66	O
had	O
diploid	O
or	O
tetraploid	O
tumors	O
,	O
12	O
of	O
56	O
had	O
MYCN	O
amplification	O
,	O
and	O
14	O
of	O
54	O
had	O
elevated	O
ferritin	O
.	O
CONCLUSIONS	O
:	O
The	O
difference	O
between	O
the	O
screened	O
and	O
clinically	O
detected	O
cases	O
was	O
highly	O
significant	O
for	O
each	O
biological	O
variable	O
.	O
Preliminary	O
data	O
on	O
other	O
biological	O
variables	O
,	O
such	O
as	O
neurotrophin	O
expression	O
and	O
allelic	O
loss	O
on	O
1	O
p	O
in	O
these	O
patients	O
are	O
consistent	O
with	O
the	O
above	O
findings	O
.	O
These	O
data	O
suggest	O
that	O
mass	O
screening	O
for	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
at	O
or	O
before	O
6	O
months	O
of	O
age	O
detects	O
almost	O
exclusively	O
tumors	O
that	O
have	O
favorable	O
biological	O
characteristics	O
,	O
many	O
of	O
which	O
might	O
have	O
regressed	O
spontaneously	O
.	O
Thus	O
,	O
continued	O
mass	O
screening	O
for	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
at	O
6	O
months	O
is	O
unlikely	O
to	O
accomplish	O
its	O
intended	O
goal	O
,	O
and	O
should	O
probably	O
be	O
discontinued	O
.	O

cell	O

Wilson	O
CD	O
,	O

W	O
,	O

GR.	O

19716	O

.	O
The	O
cytoplasmic	O
creatine	O
kinase	O
(	O
CKB	O
)	O
enzyme	O
has	O
a	O
central	O
role	O
in	O
the	O
regeneration	O
of	O
ATP	O
in	O
the	O
brain	O
.	O
We	O
have	O
shown	O
previously	O
that	O
CKB	O
mRNA	O
levels	O
in	O
cultured	O
primary	O
rat	O
brain	O
astrocytes	O
and	O
oligodendrocytes	O
are	O
much	O
higher	O
than	O
in	O
primary	O
neurons	O
.	O
It	O
has	O
been	O
suggested	O
that	O
high	O
CKB	O
expression	O
is	O
essential	O
for	O
the	O
energy-demanding	O
functions	O
of	O
glial	O
cells	O
.	O
Conversely	O
,	O
CKB	O
may	O
be	O
repressed	O
in	O
most	O
neuronal	O
cells	O
;	O
however	O
,	O
CKB	O
protein	O
has	O
previously	O
been	O
detected	O
by	O
immunohistochemistry	O
in	O
several	O
distinct	O
groups	O
of	O
neurons	O
in	O
the	O
adult	O
rodent	O
brain	O
.	O
Presently	O
,	O
little	O
is	O
known	O
of	O
the	O
factors	O
responsible	O
for	O
the	O
high	O
CKB	O
expression	O
in	O
glia	O
and	O
possible	O
repression	O
in	O
neurons	O
.	O
In	O
this	O
report	O
,	O
we	O
investigated	O
if	O
low	O
CKB	O
mRNA	O
was	O
characteristic	O
of	O
some	O
established	O
neuronal	O
cell	O
lines	O
.	O
CKB	O
mRNA	O
was	O
found	O
to	O
be	O
extremely	O
low	O
in	O
mouse	O
C1300	O
neuroblastomas	B-malignancy-type
NS20Y	O
and	O
N1E-115	O
but	O
10	O
-	O
fold	O
higher	O
in	O
NG108-15	O
,	O
a	O

cell	O

of	O

9.	O
Growth	O
patterns	O
of	O
human	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
xenografts	O
and	O
their	O
relationship	O
to	O
treatment	O
outcome	O
.	O
George	O
BA	O
,	O

,	O

RJ	O
,	O

,	O

,	O

,	O

,	O

.	O

,	O

2899	O
.	O
BACKGROUND.	O
Several	O
investigators	O
have	O
reported	O
the	O
ability	O
to	O
establish	O
xenografts	O
in	O
nude	O
mice	O
from	O
children	O
with	O
neuroblastomas	B-malignancy-type
,	O
but	O
a	O
correlation	O
of	O
prognosis	O
with	O
this	O
establishment	O
and	O
the	O
growth	O
patterns	O
of	O
the	O
neuroblastomas	B-malignancy-type
has	O
not	O
been	O
reported	O
.	O
METHODS	O
.	O
Tumor	O
specimens	O
from	O
58	O
children	O
with	O
neuroblastomas	B-malignancy-type
were	O
heterotransplanted	O
into	O
BALB/	O
c	O
nude	O
mice	O
.	O
In	O
34	O
patients	O
,	O
heterotransplantation	O
was	O
done	O
before	O
therapy	O
;	O
in	O
24	O
patients	O
,	O
tumors	O
were	O
obtained	O
after	O
at	O
least	O
one	O
course	O
of	O
chemotherapy	O
or	O
radiation	O
therapy	O
.	O
The	O
histology	O
,	O
cytogenetics	O
,	O
and	O
growth	O
characteristics	O
of	O
serial	O
passages	O
of	O
the	O
xenografts	O
were	O
studied	O
.	O
RESULTS	O
.	O
The	O
engraftment	O
rate	O
was	O
34	O
%	O
.	O
Neuroblastomas	B-malignancy-type
with	O
diploid	O
chromosome	O
numbers	O
did	O
not	O
engraft	O
.	O
Chromosomal	O
abnormalities	O
involving	O
1p	O
were	O
seen	O
in	O
more	O
than	O
50	O
%	O
of	O
the	O
xenografts	O
.	O
Cytogenetic	O
features	O
were	O
retained	O
between	O
original	O
tumors	O
and	O
resultant	O
xenografts	O
.	O
Xenografts	O
could	O
be	O
established	O
only	O
from	O
tumors	O
with	O
unfavorable	O
histology	O
,	O
as	O
defined	O
by	O
Shimada	O
classification	O
criteria	O
.	O
The	O
histology	O
of	O
each	O
xenograft	O
line	O
was	O
strikingly	O
similar	O
,	O
and	O
each	O
was	O
highly	O
undifferentiated	O
.	O
Engraftment	O
rates	O
,	O
doubling	O
times	O
,	O
and	O
lag	O
times	O
did	O
not	O
vary	O
appreciably	O
between	O
xenografts	O
established	O
from	O
treated	O
tumors	O
compared	O
with	O
xenografts	O
established	O
from	O
untreated	O
tumors	O
.	O
There	O
was	O
no	O
correlation	O
between	O
doubling	O
or	O
lag	O
times	O
and	O
prognosis	O
.	O
Patients	O
whose	O
tumors	O
engrafted	O
had	O
only	O
a	O
5	O
%	O
3-year	O
survival	O
rate	O
.	O
CONCLUSIONS	O
.	O
From	O
these	O
results	O
,	O
it	O
appears	O
that	O
successful	O
engraftment	O
is	O
the	O
most	O
important	O
prognostic	O
indicator	O
for	O
patients	O
with	O
neuroblastomas	B-malignancy-type
.	O
Because	O
of	O
the	O
commonality	O
of	O
the	O
histologic	O
features	O
and	O
the	O
stability	O
of	O
the	O
tumor	O
clones	O
from	O
patients	O
before	O
and	O
after	O
heterotransplantation	O
,	O
these	O
xenografts	O
may	O
be	O
useful	O
as	O
an	O
in	O
vivo	O
model	O
for	O
studying	O
drug	O
resistance	O
and	O
for	O
designing	O
treatment	O
regimens	O
.	O
PMID	O
:	O
8242560	O
[	O

-	O
indexed	O
for	O

INTRODUCTION	O
:	O
Considerable	O
controversy	O
exists	O
regarding	O
the	O
appropriate	O
management	O
of	O
spinal	O
involvement	O
in	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
(	O
NB	B-malignancy-type
)	O
patients	O
.	O
We	O
review	O
a	O
large	O
group	O
of	O
such	O
patients	O
and	O
offer	O
treatment	O
recommendations	O
.	O
METHODS	O
:	O
Forty	O
-six	O
patients	O
with	O
epidural	O
and/or	O
neural	O
foraminal	O
involvement	O
treated	O
between	O
1987	O
and	O
1998	O
were	O
staged	O
according	O
to	O
the	O
International	O
NB	B-malignancy-type
Staging	O
System	O
(	O
INSS	O
)	O
and	O
classified	O
as	O
high	O
-risk	O
(	O
INSS	O
stage	O
4	O
;	O
n	O
=	O
31	O
)	O
or	O
low-risk	O
(	O
INSS	O
stage	O
<4	O
;	O
n	O
=	O
15	O
)	O
.	O
Of	O
13	O
high	O
-	O
risk	O
patients	O
with	O
normal	O
neurologic	O
examinations	O
and	O
no	O
radiographic	O
high-grade	O
spinal	O
cord	O
compression	O
(	O
HGSCC	O
)	O
,	O
12	O
were	O
treated	O
initially	O
with	O
chemotherapy	O
,	O
and	O
only	O
1	O
demonstrated	O
neurologic	O
deterioration	O
.	O
HGSCC	O
was	O
present	O
in	O
18	O
patients	O
with	O
high	O
-risk	O
NB	B-malignancy-type
;	O
7	O
of	O
10	O
(	O
70	O
%	O
)	O
treated	O
initially	O
with	O
chemotherapy	O
and	O
6	O
of	O
6	O
(	O
100	O
%	O
)	O
managed	O
initially	O
with	O
operation	O
improved	O
or	O
remained	O
stable	O
.	O
All	O
9	O
low-risk	O
patients	O
with	O
normal	O

examinations	O
and	O
no	O
HGSCC	O
remained	O

(	O
n	O
=	O
7	O
)	O

(	O

=	O
2	O
)	O
.	O

4	O
low-risk	O
patients	O
with	O

treated	O
with	O
operations	O
improved	O
or	O
remained	O
stable	O
,	O
and	O
0	O
of	O
2	O
(	O
0	O
%	O
)	O

initially	O

stable	O
.	O
Spinal	O
deformities	O
occurred	O
in	O
2	O
of	O
16	O
patients	O
(	O
12.5	O
%	O
)	O

and	O

9	O
of	O
30	O
(	O

%	O
)	O
who	O
underwent	O
operations	O
.	O
CONCLUSIONS	O
:	O
High	O
-risk	O
NB	B-malignancy-type
patients	O
with	O
spinal	O
involvement	O
but	O
normal	O
neurologic	O
examinations	O
should	O
be	O
offered	O
chemotherapy	O
.	O
High	O
-risk	O
patients	O
with	O
HGSCC	O
may	O
respond	O
to	O
chemotherapy	O
,	O
but	O
a	O
small	O
percentage	O
will	O
require	O
operations	O
for	O
progressive	O
neurologic	O
deficits	O
.	O
Chemotherapy	O
may	O
be	O
avoided	O
in	O
low-risk	O
patients	O
who	O
are	O
offered	O
potentially	O
curative	O
operations	O
.	O
Patients	O
treated	O
with	O
operations	O
for	O
epidural	O
disease	O
are	O
at	O
high	O
risk	O
of	O
subsequently	O
developing	O
spinal	O
deformity	O
.	O

Aminohexanoic	O
hydroxamate	O
is	O
a	O
potent	O
inducer	O
of	O
the	O

of	O

cells	O
.	O
Lu	O
J,	O
Chen	O

,	O

,	O

of	O
New	O
Jersey	O
,Piscataway	O
,	O
NJ	O
08854	O
-8087	O
,	O
USA	O
.	O
Deoxyhypusine	O
synthase	O
is	O
the	O
key	O
enzyme	O
for	O
modifying	O
a	O
lysine	O
residue	O
to	O
hypusine	O
in	O
the	O
cellular	O
protein	O
eukaryotic	O
initiation	O
factor	O
5A	O
(	O
eIF-5A	O
)	O
.	O
Deletion	O
of	O
the	O
deoxyhypusine	O
synthase	O
or	O
the	O
eIF-5A	O
gene	O
in	O
yeast	O
produces	O
lethal	O
phenotype	O
.	O
Inhibition	O
of	O
deoxyhypusine	O
synthase	O
by	O
1-guanidino-	O
7-aminoheptane	O
(	O
GC7	O
)	O
suppresses	O
tumor	O
cell	O
growth	O
.	O
Hypusine	O
formation	O
represents	O
one	O
of	O
the	O
most	O
specific	O
polyamine	O
-	O
dependent	O
biochemical	O
reactions	O
.	O
In	O
view	O
of	O
the	O
importance	O
of	O
polyamines	O
in	O
growth	O
regulation	O
and	O
cancer	O
biology	O
,	O
deoxyhypusine	O
synthase	O
has	O
been	O
considered	O
to	O
be	O
a	O
good	O
target	O
for	O
chemotherapeutic	O
drug	O
design	O
.	O
Using	O
GC7	O
as	O
a	O
prototype	O
we	O
have	O
synthesized	O
and	O
tested	O
three	O
classes	O
of	O
diamine	O
analogs	O
,	O
namely	O
,	O
guanidino	O
-	O
,	O
pyrimidino	O
-	O
,	O
and	O
hydroxamate	O
derivatives	O
,	O
as	O
potential	O
inhibitors	O
for	O
deoxyhypusine	O
synthase	O
.	O
Our	O
study	O
shows	O
that	O
(	O
i)	O
among	O
all	O
the	O
compounds	O
tested	O
,	O
GC7	O
remained	O
to	O
be	O
the	O
most	O
potent	O
inhibitor	O
for	O
deoxyhypusine	O
synthase	O
;	O
(ii)	O
N,N'-bispyrimidino-1	O
,	O
9-diaminononane	O
,	O
although	O
a	O
poor	O
inhibitor	O
of	O
deoxyhypusine	O
synthase	O
,	O
was	O
a	O
potent	O
growth	O
inhibitor	O
;	O
and	O
(iii)	O
one	O
of	O
the	O
hydroxamate	O
derivatives	O
,	O
6-aminohexanoic	O
hydroxamate	O
(	O
HC6	O
)	O
,	O
prominently	O
induced	O
the	O
differentiation	O
of	O
mouse	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
cells	O
at	O
sub-millimolar	O
concentrations	O
.	O
Interestingly	O
,	O
other	O
hydroxamates	O
with	O
different	O
chain	O
length	O
were	O
not	O
nearly	O
as	O
effective	O
as	O
HC6	O
in	O
inducing	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
cell	O
differentiation	O
.	O
The	O
effect	O
of	O
HC6	O
was	O
also	O
unique	O
in	O
that	O
it	O
could	O
induce	O
neurite	O
outgrowth	O
and	O
the	O
expression	O
of	O
neuron	O
-	O
specific	O
genes	O
such	O
as	O
synapsin	O
I	O
and	O
MAP-2	O
in	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
cells	O
in	O
the	O
absence	O
of	O
other	O
promoting	O
agents	O
such	O
as	O
cAMP	O
.	O
The	O
effect	O
of	O
HC6	O
on	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
cell	O
differentiation	O
was	O
comparable	O
with	O
,	O
or	O
better	O
than	O
that	O
of	O
N(	O
6)	O
,O(2)	O
'-dibutyryl	O
cAMP	O
(	O
Bt(2)cAMP	O
)	O
,	O
a	O
standard	O
reagent	O
commonly	O
used	O
for	O
inducing	O
the	O
differentiation	O
of	O
mouse	O
and	O
human	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
cells	O
in	O
culture	O
.	O

:	O

dmartine@fisio.cinvestav.mx	O
We	O
report	O
herein	O
the	O
synthesis	O
of	O
a	O
novel	O
DNA	O
delivery	O
system	O
and	O
in	O
vitro	O
evidence	O
of	O
its	O
ability	O
to	O
transfect	O
cell	O
lines	O
by	O
binding	O
to	O
the	O
high	O
-	O
affinity	O
neurotensin	O
receptor	O
and	O
subsequent	O
internalization	O
of	O
ligand	O
-	O
receptor	O
complexes	O
.	O
The	O
targeting	O
vehicle	O
consisted	O
of	O
neurotensin	O
crosslinked	O
with	O
poly-L-lysine	O
via	O
N-	O
succinimidyl-3-(2-pyridyldithio	O
)	O
propionate	O
(	O
SPDP	O
)	O
.	O
The	O
SPDP-derivatives	O
with	O
either	O
neurotensin	O
or	O
poly-L-lysine	O
were	O
purified	O
by	O
gel	O
filtration	O
.	O
The	O
conjugate	O
resulting	O
of	O
the	O
reaction	O
of	O
neurotensin	O
-	O
SPDP	O
with	O
HS-SPDP-	O
poly-L-lysine	O
was	O
purified	O
through	O
Biogel	O
A	O
1.5	O
.	O
The	O
neurotensin	O
-	O
SPDP	O
-	O
poly-L-lysine	O
conjugate	O
was	O
able	O
to	O
bind	O
plasmidic	O
DNAs	O
(	O
pSV2cat	O
and	O
pGreen	O
Lantern	O
-1	O
)	O
at	O
optimal	O
molar	O
ratios	O
of	O
1	O
:	O
5	O
and	O
1	O
:	O
6	O
(	O
DNA	O
:	O
conjugate	O
)	O
,	O
respectively	O
.	O
The	O
conjugate	O
internalized	O
those	O
plasmids	O
in	O
the	O
cell	O
lines	O
(	O
N1E-115	O
and	O
HT-29	O
)	O
bearing	O
the	O
high	O
-	O
affinity	O
neurotensin	O
receptor	O
.	O
Expression	O
of	O
the	O
plasmid	O
products	O
,	O
chloramphenicol	O
acetyltransferase	O
and	O
green	O
fluorescent	O
protein	O
,	O
was	O
observed	O
in	O
such	O
cell	O
lines	O
.	O
Both	O
internalization	O
and	O
expression	O
of	O
the	O
plasmids	O
transferred	O
by	O
the	O
neurotensin	O
-	O
SPDP	O
-	O
poly-L-lysine	O
conjugate	O
were	O
prevented	O
by	O
neurotensin	O
(	O
1	O
microM	O
)	O
and	O
SR-48692	O
(	O
100	O
nM	O
)	O
,	O
a	O
specific	O
antagonist	O
of	O
the	O
high	O
-	O
affinity	O
neurotensin	O
receptor	O
.	O
The	O
neurotensin	O
-	O
SPDP	O
-	O
poly-L-lysine	O
conjugate	O
was	O
unable	O
to	O
transfect	O
cell	O
lines	O
lacking	O
the	O
neurotensin	O
receptor	O
(	O
COS-7	O
and	O
L-929	O
)	O
.	O
In	O
rat	O
brain	O
,	O
the	O
high	O
-	O
affinity	O
neurotensin	O
receptor	O
is	O
expressed	O
by	O
specific	O

such	O
as	O
those	O
of	O
the	O
nigrostriatal	O
and	O
mesolimbic	O
dopaminergic	O
systems	O
.	O
Therefore	O
,	O
the	O
neurotensin	O
-	O

-	O

be	O
a	O

systems	O

Molecular	O
cloning	O
of	O
human	O
5-hydroxytryptamine3	O
receptor	O
:	O

in	O
distribution	O
and	O
function	O
among	O
species	O
.	O
Miyake	O
A	O
,	O
Mochizuki	O
S	O
,	O
Takemoto	O
Y	O
,	O
Akuzawa	O
S.	O
Molecular	O
Medicine	O
Research	O
Laboratory	O
,	O
Yamanouchi	O
Pharmaceutical	O
Co.	O

Ltd.	O

.	O
The	O
5-hydroxytryptamine3	O
receptor	O
5-HT3R	O
has	O
been	O
implicated	O
in	O
gut	O
and	O
cardiac	O
motility	O
and	O
in	O
behavioral	O
disorders	O
.	O
Characteristics	O
of	O
5-HT3Rs	O
appear	O
to	O
be	O
heterogeneous	O
among	O
species	O
,	O
but	O
human	O
5-HT3R	O
cDNA	O
has	O
not	O
been	O
identified	O
.	O
We	O
isolated	O
a	O
cDNA	O
encoding	O
5-HT3R	O
from	O
human	O
hippocampus	O
.	O
The	O
mouse	O
5-HT3R	O
gene	O
has	O
been	O
reported	O
to	O
generate	O
two	O
alternative	O
splicing	O
isoforms	O
that	O
differ	O
by	O
six	O
amino	O
acids	O
.	O
All	O
of	O
our	O
isolated	O
human	O
clones	O
corresponded	O
to	O
the	O
shorter	O
isoform	O
.	O
Amino	O
acid	O
identities	O
with	O
mouse	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
N1E-115	O
and	O
rat	O
brain	O
5-HT3Rs	O
were	O
84	O
%	O
for	O
each	O
.	O
Southern	O
blot	O
analysis	O
of	O
human	O
genomic	O
DNA	O
suggested	O
that	O
our	O
cloned	O
transcript	O
encoded	O
a	O
human	O
counterpart	O
for	O
the	O
rodent	O
5-HT3Rs	O
.	O
This	O
gene	O
was	O
assigned	O
to	O
chromosome	O
11	O
using	O
polymerase	O
chain	O
reaction	O
analysis	O
of	O
a	O
human	O
/	O
rodent	O
somatic	O
cell	O
hybrid	O
panel	O
.	O
With	O
the	O
use	O
of	O
Northern	O
blot	O
analysis	O
,	O
5-HT3R	O
transcripts	O
were	O
identified	O
in	O
human	O
small	O
intestine	O
,	O
colon	O
,	O
and	O
brain	O
regions	O
including	O
hippocampus	O
,	O
amygdala	O
,	O
and	O
striatum	O
.	O
In	O
human	O
heart	O
,	O
5-HT3R	O
expression	O
was	O
not	O
detectable	O
even	O
with	O
reverse	O
transcriptase	O
-	O
polymerase	O
chain	O
reaction	O
analysis	O
,	O
although	O
it	O
was	O
detectable	O
in	O
mouse	O
heart	O
.	O
Transfection	O
of	O
COS-1	O
with	O
human	O
5-HT3R	O
cDNA	O
induced	O
specific	O
binding	O
of	O
the	O
5-HT3R	O
-	O
selective	O
radioligand	O
[3H]YM060	O
.	O
Human	O
5-HT3R	O
showed	O
typical	O
characteristics	O
of	O
the	O
5-HT3R	O
,	O
but	O
its	O
affinity	O
for	O
the	O
5-HT3R	O
agonist	O
m-	O
chlorophenylbiguanide	O
was	O
much	O
lower	O
than	O
that	O
of	O
rat	O
5-HT3R	O
.	O
When	O
injected	O
with	O
human	O
5-HT3R	O
cRNA	O
,	O
the	O
oocytes	O
responded	O
to	O
5-HT3R	O
agonists	O
with	O
a	O
rapidly	O
developing	O
inward	O
current	O
.	O
The	O
potency	O
of	O
the	O
agonists	O
to	O
induce	O
inward	O
current	O
paralleled	O
that	O
to	O
compete	O
with	O
the	O
radioligand	O
binding	O
,	O
and	O
2-methyl-	O
5-hydroxytryptamine	O
,	O
a	O
partial	O
agonist	O
for	O
mouse	O
5-HT3R	O
,	O
was	O
a	O
full	O
agonist	O
for	O
human	O
5-HT3R	O
.	O
Our	O
data	O
revealed	O
that	O
the	O

Parkinson	O
's	O
disease	O
(	O
PD	O
)	O
is	O
a	O
severe	O
neurological	O
disorder	O
,	O
characterized	O
by	O
the	O
progressive	O
degeneration	O
of	O
the	O
dopaminergic	O
nigrostriatal	O
pathway	O
and	O
the	O
presence	O
of	O
Lewy	O
bodies	O
(	O
LBs	O
)	O
.	O
The	O
discovery	O
of	O
genes	O
responsible	O
for	O
familial	O
forms	O
of	O
the	O
disease	O
has	O
provided	O
insights	O
into	O
its	O
pathogenesis	O
.	O
Mutations	O
in	O
the	O
parkin	O
gene	O
,	O
which	O
encodes	O
an	O
E3	O
ubiquitin	O
-	O
protein	O
ligase	O
involved	O
in	O
the	O
ubiquitylation	O
and	O
proteasomal	O
degradation	O
of	O
specific	O
protein	O
substrates	O
,	O
have	O
been	O
found	O
in	O
nearly	O
50	O
%	O
of	O
patients	O
with	O
autosomal	O
-	O
recessive	O
early-onset	O
parkinsonism	O
.	O
The	O
abnormal	O
accumulation	O
of	O
substrates	O
due	O
to	O
loss	O
of	O
Parkin	O
function	O
may	O
be	O
the	O
cause	O
of	O
neurodegeneration	O
in	O
parkin	O
-	O
related	O
parkinsonism	O
.	O
Here	O
,	O
we	O
demonstrate	O
that	O
Parkin	O
interacts	O
with	O
,	O
ubiquitylates	O
and	O

the	O
degradation	O
of	O
p38	O
,	O
a	O
key	O
structural	O
component	O
of	O
the	O
mammalian	O
aminoacyl-tRNA	O
synthetase	O
complex	O
.	O
We	O
found	O
that	O
the	O

of	O
p38	O
is	O
abrogated	O
by	O
truncated	O
variants	O
of	O

lacking	O
essential	O

domains	O
,	O
but	O
not	O
by	O
the	O
pathogenic	O
Lys	O
161	O
Asn	O
point	O
mutant	O
.	O

of	O
p38	O
in	O

.	O

PURPOSE	O
:	O
To	O
determine	O
the	O
relationship	O
between	O
multiple	O

features	O
,	O
tumor	O
morphology	O
,	O
and	O
prognosis	O
in	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
.	O
PATIENTS	O
AND	O
METHODS	O
:	O
The	O
genetic	O
alterations	O
and	O
morphologic	O
features	O
that	O
underpin	O
three	O
histopathologic	O
risk	O
classifications	O
were	O
analyzed	O
in	O
108	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
patients	O
.	O
Tumors	O
were	O
subdivided	O
into	O
four	O
groups	O
based	O
on	O
the	O
three	O
most	O
frequent	O
and	O
prognostically	O
significant	O

alterations	O
(	O
17q	O
gain	O
,	O
1p	O
deletion	O
,	O
and	O
MYCN	O
amplification	O
)	O
,	O
and	O
all	O
other	O
genetic	O
,	O
morphologic	O
,	O
and	O
clinical	O
data	O
were	O
analyzed	O
with	O
respect	O
to	O
these	O
groups	O
.	O
RESULTS	O
:	O
Our	O
analyses	O
identify	O
three	O
nonoverlapping	O
tumor	O
types	O
with	O
distinct	O
genetic	O
and	O

features	O
,	O
defined	O
here	O
as	O
types	O
1	O
,	O
2	O
,	O
and	O
3	O
.	O
Type	O
1	O
tumors	O
show	O
none	O
of	O
the	O
three	O
significant	O
genetic	O
alterations	O
and	O
have	O
good	O
prognosis	O
.	O
Both	O
type	O
2	O
(	O
17q	O
gain	O
only	O
or	O
17q	O
gain	O
and	O
1p	O
del	O
)	O
and	O
type	O
3	O
(	O
17q	O
gain	O
,	O
1p	O
del	O
,	O
and	O
MYCN	O
amplification	O
)	O
tumors	O
progress	O
.	O

,	O
these	O
tumor	O
types	O
are	O

by	O
having	O

median	O

and	O
median	O

(	O

)	O
.	O

that	O

gain	O
is	O
the	O
only	O

prognostic	O
factor	O
among	O
all	O

,	O

,	O
and	O
clinical	O
factors	O
analyzed	O
.	O
Among	O
histopathologic	O
risk	O
systems	O
,	O
the	O
International	O
Neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
Pathology	O
Classification	O
was	O
the	O
best	O

of	O
PFS	O
.	O

:	O

that	O

to	O

and	O

.	O

.	O
alpha-Melanocyte	O
-	O
stimulating	O
hormone	O
(	O
MSH	O
)	O
utilizes	O
cAMP	O
to	O
trigger	O
pigmentation	O
of	O
melanocytes	O
via	O
activation	O
of	O
melanocyte	O
-	O
restricted	O
microphthalmia	O
-	O
associated	O
transcription	O
factor	O
(	O
M-MITF	O
)	O
expression	O
.	O
M-MITF	O
is	O
a	O
melanocyte	O
-	O
restricted	O
helix-loop-helix	O
transcription	O
factor	O
capable	O
of	O
transactivating	O
promoters	O
for	O
multiple	O
genes	O
whose	O
products	O
modulate	O
pigmentation	O
.	O
Although	O
M-MITF	O
promoter	O
activation	O
by	O
MSH	O
is	O
known	O
to	O
occur	O
through	O
a	O
conserved	O
cAMP	O
-response	O
element	O
(	O
CRE	O
)	O
,	O
it	O
remains	O
unclear	O
how	O
this	O
CRE	O
exhibits	O
such	O
exquisitely	O
tissue	O
-	O
restricted	O
responsiveness	O
.	O
Here	O
we	O
show	O
that	O
cAMP	O
-	O
mediated	O
CRE-binding	O
protein	O
activation	O
of	O
the	O
M-MITF	O
promoter	O
requires	O
a	O
second	O
DNA	O
element	O
located	O
approximately	O
100	O
bp	O
upstream	O
,	O
a	O
site	O
that	O
is	O
bound	O
and	O
activated	O
by	O
SOX10	O
.	O
Mutations	O
in	O
the	O
SOX10	O
transcription	O
factor	O
,	O
like	O
MITF	O
,	O
results	O
in	O
a	O
disorder	O
known	O
as	O
Waardenburg	O
Syndrome	O
.	O
The	O
cAMP	O
response	O
of	O
the	O
M-MITF	O
promoter	O
was	O
analyzed	O
in	O
melanoma	B-malignancy-type
and	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
cells	O
(	O
which	O
are	O
neural	O
crest	O
-	O
derived	O
but	O
lack	O
both	O
M-MITF	O
and	O
SOX10	O
expression	O
)	O
.	O
M-MITF	O
promoter	O
responsiveness	O
to	O
cAMP	O
was	O
found	O
to	O
depend	O
upon	O
SOX10	O
,	O
and	O
reciprocally	O
,	O
SOX10	O
transactivation	O
was	O
dependent	O
upon	O
the	O
CRE.	O

SOX10	O
expression	O
,	O
in	O
cooperation	O
with	O
cAMP	O
signaling	O
,	O
activated	O
the	O
M-MITF	O
promoter	O
function	O
and	O
the	O
expression	O
of	O
measurable	O
endogenous	O

transcripts	O
in	O
neuroblastoma	B-malignancy-type
cells	O
.	O
SOX10dom	O
,	O
a	O
mutant	O
allele	O

failed	O

attenuated	O

responsiveness	O
of	O

promoter	O
in	O
melanoma	B-malignancy-type

.	O
